GoPro (GPRO) hopes to get some big mo with its fourth-quarter earnings due out after the close Thursday.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect the maker of Hero-brand action cameras to earn 70 cents a share minus items, up 94% year over year, on sales of $580 million, up 60%, for the holiday quarter.For the March quarter, Wall Street is modeling GoPro to earn 17 cents a share ex items, up 42%, on $325 million in sales, up 38%.GoPro was a darling of investors last fall after the company's successful IPO. GoPro went public on June 26 at 24 and climbed to an all-time high of 98.47 on Oct. 7. Since then, it's lost roughly half its value.GoPro stock was down 5% in early afternoon trading on the stock market today, near 52. Citigroup slashed its price target on GoPro stock to 59 from 94 on Wednesday and maintained a neutral rating.Dougherty & Company analyst Charles Anderson also has neutral rating on GoPro, saying the consumer electronics vendor is overvalued."We believe GoPro has established itself as one of the most valuable brands in consumer technology and has significant headroom to grow as it expands overseas," Anderson said in a research report Wednesday. "That said, the post-IPO move in the stock has priced in outstanding performance as GPRO trades at 43x our FY15 EPS estimate of $1.18."That multiple is higher than the highest multiple Apple (AAPL) has traded at in the entire iPod/iPhone/iPad era. In terms of an entry point, we would prefer a multiple in the high 20s or low 30s."GoPro likely will beat Q4 estimates, based on retail data, Anderson said."We continue to like the story, but we believe GoPro needs additional chapters, which could be growing its media business, expanding into new geographies, or moving into new verticals for capture, such as drones," he said.Meanwhile, Ambarella (AMBA), which supplies video processors for GoPro cameras, has been outpacing its customer on the stock market. Ambarella shares are up more than 10% this year, while GoPro stock is down about 18%.But Wedbush analyst Michael Pachter says the sell-off in GoPro shares is "overdone" and expects a rebound on strong Q4 results."We expect positive momentum to carry into 2015 as holiday demand outpaced supply," Pachter said in a research note Sunday. He says the sell-off was partly due to speculation that Apple might launch a competing product, based on patent filings.Pachter rates GoPro stock as outperform, with a 12-month price target of 98.RELATED:GoPro skates into pro sports with NHL deal.
Google's (GOOGL) capital spending popped 57% in Q4 to $3.55 billion, topping Wall Street estimates, and the Internet search giant's cash balance rose 10.6% to nearly $60 billion.
Despite its heavy investments, Google could start paying a dividend like Apple (AAPL), RBC Capital speculated late last year.

In Q4, Google's capital spending accounted for 20% of gross revenue, up from 14% in the year-earlier quarter and 8% in Q4 2012. On Google's earnings call, executives said the Q4 increase was partly due to one-time projects. Google cited $900 million of real estate expenditures, including $585 million related to a project in Redwood City, Calif.
Google late Thursday posted Q4 results that missed on the top and bottom lines.

On the company's earnings conference call, Google "hinted at a limit for the amount of investment that it can 'manageably absorb,'" wrote Evan Wilson, an analyst at Pacific Crest Securities, in a research report. "While it was not made explicit, it appears that Google is going to seek a better balance between growth and cost discipline in 2015.

"After sustaining the margin contraction that it has in 2014, Google's message should be well received by shareholders. Google will continue to be a big spender, but it sounds like it is moving back to more rational spending and changing its tune to the Street about expenses going forward. To us, this was the most positive takeaway from the Q4 call."
Brian Wieser, an analyst at Pivotal Research Group, is cautious on capital spending.

"Q4 capital expenditures and acquisitions were $3.8 billion, much heavier than the $2 billion we forecast," Wieser wrote in a report. "Total capital expenditures and acquisitions for the year amounted to $15.8 billion, equating to approximately two-thirds of the company's $24 billion in cash generated from operations in 2014. While capex presumably could abate somewhat over time, we think that it will generally trend higher as the company continues to invest in new endeavors which are commonly unrelated to the core business."

A big chunk of Google's Q4 capital spending went toward data center construction. Amazon Web Services, part of e-commerce giant Amazon.com (AMZN), Google and Microsoft (MSFT) have been racing to build out data center capacity for cloud computing services, as IBD has reported.

Google on Tuesday said it would expand its superfast broadband service to four more cities: Atlanta; Charlotte, N.C.; Raleigh-Durham, N.C.; and Nashville, Tenn. The 1 gigabit-per-second Google Fiber service has already been built out in parts of Kansas City, Mo.; Kansas City, Kan.; Austin, Texas; and Provo, Utah.
About 60% of Google's cash is overseas, notes Mark Mahaney, an analyst at RBC Capital.

"We believe maintaining a healthy cash balance is important for Google's strategic flexibility and further believe that much of this would be difficult to repatriate in a tax efficient manner," Mahaney said in a report published on Friday.

Law And Order: As President Obama's government wages its War on Cops, a new report finds a 56% jump in cop-killings — many ambushed and shot by black suspects, just like the two NYPD officers executed in Brooklyn.The mainstream media have written off the Dec. 20 shooting deaths of NYPD officers Wenjian Liu and Rafael Ramos as an "isolated incident," arguing the real threat is from white cops "targeting" black men.They say their black killer, Ismaaiyl Abdullah Brinsley, was "deranged" when he sneaked up to their parked patrol car and shot them in the head. They dismissed his vengeful act as a "one-off" or "lone" event.In fact, Liu and Ramos were two of 50 law enforcement officers shot and killed in the line of duty in 2014. That number is up 56% from 2013, when 32 gun-related police deaths were reported, according to the National Law Enforcement Officers Memorial Fund.Brinsley was hardly alone in targeting and ambushing police. His attack was more of a copycat crime. "Fifteen officers were shot and killed in ambush, more than any other circumstance of fatal shootings, in 2014," said the Washington-based police fund.The White House and its press popinjays have made great hay of the racial element in the Ferguson, Mo., and Staten Island, N.Y., cases involving black suspects who died while resisting arrest.But they completely overlook the race factor in recent shootings of police. Here is a sampling: December: Marco Antonio Parilla Jr. allegedly shot and killed — and even ran over — Tarpon Springs (Fla.) officer Charles Kondek after the former NYPD cop responded to a noise complaint at a home near Tampa. Parilla, 23, is biracial, while Kondek, 45, was white. July: Police say Lawrence Campbell, a 27-year-old African-American, ambushed and murdered Jersey City, N.J., police officer Melvin Santiago and his partner after they answered a robbery-in-progress call at a drugstore. Santiago, 23, was gunned down in a hail of bullets fired by the ex-con, who moments earlier boasted to a bystander he was "going to be famous." July: Carl Le'Ellis Blount Jr., a 25-year-old black man, was charged in the shooting death of Gary, Ind., police officer Jeffrey Westerfield, who was white. Westerfield was responding to a shots-fired call in a domestic dispute when Blount allegedly shot him while he sat in his squad car. The officer, who would have turned 47 that day, never even pulled his weapon before he was shot in the head. July: Authorities say Major Davis Jr. shot and killed Indianapolis police officer Perry Renn after the 25-year-old black suspect brandished an assault rifle and Renn and another officer confronted him. Davis refused orders to put the gun down, and a five-minute gun battle ensued. Twenty-two-year veteran Renn, who was white, died shortly after being struck by bullets, while Davis survived surgery from his gunshot wounds. June: Two young black men — Quintylan Richard, 20, and Baylon Taylor, 19 — allegedly murdered Vermilion Parish, La., Sheriff's Deputy Allen Bares, as the 51-year-old officer investigated a home break-in. The white officer was shot several times. May: Police say Marvin Louis Guy shot Killeen, Texas, Police Det. Charles "Chuck" Dinwiddie in the face as he and SWAT officers served a warrant at his home. Guy is black, Dinwiddie was white. The 50-year-old Guy, who allegedly wounded two other officers in the assault, faces one count of capital murder and three counts of attempted capital murder.Evidence clearly shows police face a lethal and growing threat from black criminals. So when will the pundits talk about this disturbing trend?
Dividend mutual funds pursue a variety of strategies, from capturing high yields to focusing on rising payouts.
They fit well in retirement.

The average dividend fund's performance has stayed above the S&P 500 in the past 15 years. It would have turned an investment of $10,000 made on Sept. 30, 1999, into $26,355 by Dec. 17 this year, according to Morningstar data. The same investment in the S&P 500, a proxy for the broad stock market, would have grown to $20,929.

Delaware Dividend Income Fund has produced an average annual return of 7.18% in the past 15 years vs. 4.31% for the S&P 500. The $762 million fund has handed investors a 6% gain this year vs. 11% for the S&P 500.

The fund has a 12-month yield of 2.29%, while the S&P 500 yields 1.87%. The fund's recent holdings include Lowe's (LOW). The home-improvement retailer is up 34% this year and well extended past a flat base that it broke out above in August.

War On Cops: As two NYPD officers were laid to rest, deadly attacks against police have exploded across the country, the outcome of leftist anti-police protests. The left can't wash its hands of this with phony tears at funerals.The murdered New York officers Rafael Ramos and Wenjian Liu were barely in their graves after being eulogized by Vice President Joe Biden and New York Mayor Bill de Blasio when new attacks — from targeted shootings to credible Internet threats — flared up across the land.In Durham, N.C., police were shot at in an unprovoked Christmas night attack, while on Sunday officers were shot at with rifles in Los Angeles, prompting a citywide alert. There was another shooting in the Tampa Bay area of Florida. And 11 would-be shooters in Chicago, Pennsylvania and New York all posted credible Internet threats.In an atmosphere like this, it's pretty obvious that there's a war against the police, and not surprisingly the security of all law-abiding people is already suffering.On Monday, the New York Post reported that police were refraining from enforcing penalties for small crimes now, fearful of any confrontation that might inflame racial tensions.That's exceptionally bad news, given that New York was cured of its ugly "Shattered" and "Fun City" reality (as Mick Jagger and Bill Buckley respectively put it) only by Mayor Rudy Giuliani's emphasis on enforcing punishment for small crimes so that large ones could not occur — the so-called "broken windows theory" of law enforcement.There's little doubt where the blame lies: with the race-baiters and communist organizing groups who have taken their cues from the wink-and-nod encouragement from political leaders at the top.Leaders from President Obama to de Blasio have embraced the radical "narrative" that all police are "Bull Connor"-style predators on black people, along with the de facto message that the police do not have the right to defend themselves in a confrontation.That was clearly evident in these political leaders' stances in favor of mob protests over grand jury rulings, first in Ferguson, Mo., when a thug attacked a cop to a bad end. It was the cop, cleared by a grand jury, who was forced to resign amid protests. Similar incidents occured in New York and Cleveland.It didn't help that Obama used race-baiter Al Sharpton as a go-to man on race, inviting the "leader" to the White House 81 times. It also didn't help that he made apologetic remarks to the U.N. about Ferguson, again underlining that police have no right to self-defense.With a message like that, it shouldn't surprise anyone that thugs with rifles and an urge to scream fire in a crowded theatre would act up — and very quickly.It's a disastrous and foolish action, effectively announcing to criminals that the consequences for hunting down cops is nonexistent to small.Personal security is the foremost of human rights, as writer Robert Young Pelton has noted, and there's no disputing that cops protect far more than they harm.It's time for a serious response from political leaders, because the fire this time has already started.

Google (GOOGL) might start paying a dividend to shareholders, despite its soaring capital spending and plans to expand cloud computing and Internet broadband services, speculates RBC Capital Markets in a report.
In its "Top 10 Internet Surprises for 2015" report, RBC says Google could have $80 billion in cash and marketable securities by the end of 2015.

"That's not too far off from the level — $100 billion-ish — when Apple (AAPL) announced that it would begin paying a dividend," said RBC analysts Mark Mahaney and Rohit Kulkarni in the report. "And we believe that Google management does pay particular attention to Apple's activities. So perhaps Google will begin to return cash.

Google's capital spending jumped 45% in the first nine months of 2014 to $7.4 billion. Google has been racing with Amazon Web Services, part of e-commerce giant Amazon.com (AMZN), and Microsoft (MSFT) to build out cloud computing infrastructure. AWS, Google and Microsoft's Azure unit are the biggest providers of infrastructure-as-a-service, where customers rent computer servers and data storage systems via the Internet.

AWS, Google and Microsoft have been packing warehouse-sized data centers with servers and data-storage divisions. The trio could have a combined capital spending of $18 billion in 2014, up 93% from $9.4 billion in 2012, Pacific Crest Securities forecast in August.

Google, meanwhile, has been delayed in announcing an update of expansion plans for its superfast broadband service, another capital intensive project. The Google Fiber service provides Internet access at speeds of 1 gigabit per second. That's roughly 100 times faster than what most U.S. households get on average.

Google has already built out fiber-optic networks in parts of Kansas City, Mo.; Kansas City, Kan.; Austin, Texas; and Provo, Utah. Google has been in talks to bring its Google Fiber service to as many as 34 cities and suburbs in nine U.S. markets: Phoenix; Portland, Ore.; San Jose, Calif.; Salt Lake City; San Antonio; Nashville, Tenn.; Atlanta; and North Carolina's Charlotte and Raleigh/Durham.

Phone company AT&T (T) and privately held cable TV firm Cox Communications have been expanding their own gigabit-speed services in anticipation of growing competition with Google. Mike McCarty has watched people job-search for 25 years. McCarty, now volunteer executive director of Ballwin, Mo.-based Businesspersons Between Jobs, first came to BBJ as a job-seeker himself.
During the worst of the recent recession, BBJ hosted 80-120 job-seekers a week. Now that's down to about 20, McCarty said.

"Part of it is people getting more jobs, part of it is people working what I call 'beneath their station,'" he said. "That seems to be a dark underside of the economy, where the numbers don't tell the whole story. ... People aren't making the money they used to and aren't as happy as they used to be."

By many measures, the job market is booming like the dot-com era. Employers have added an average of 241,000 jobs per month in 2014, the best since 1999. The jobless rate has fallen nearly a full percentage point in the last year.
But McCarty isn't the only one wondering whether the brighter economy has a "dark underside."

"There is room for further improvement," Federal Reserve Chairwoman Janet Yellen said Dec. 17, "with too many people who want jobs being unable to find them, too many who are working part time but would prefer full-time work, and too many who have given up searching for a job but would likely do so if the labor market were stronger."
Many Fed policymakers cite these "underemployed" to explain why they think the U.S. still needs monetary policy support.
There were 4.8 million job openings in October, the latest data available from the Labor Department. That's the second-highest level since January 2001.
Structural Problem?

But 2.8 million people, known as the long-term unemployed, have been out of work longer than 27 weeks. Nearly 7 million are working part-time jobs involuntarily. Another 700,000 are "discouraged," meaning that they hadn't bothered to search for work in the last four weeks. And labor force participation remains at long-time lows while disability rolls have exploded.
"We've had 57 straight months of positive growth," said Carl Van Horn, director of the Heldrich Center for Workforce Development at Rutgers University. But "we still have major problems."

At some point the situation may become structural, and economic growth alone won't help. For example, the longer the long-term unemployed are out of work and their skills atrophy, the harder it will be for them to return, Van Horn said.
If the underemployed do re-enter the workforce, many economists fear their inability to command the same salaries as those who've worked without interruption may push all wages down.
"They're going to have less money and lower mobility," Van Horn said. "That means the overall economy is not as large because there are less people in the workforce.
"We've got to get the labor force participation rate up," he added. "I think we should be moving in that direction both for the individuals and for the whole society."
Trends Finally Improving
Some experts are optimistic.

"We're in the seventh inning of an expansion," said John Challenger, CEO of placement firm Challenger, Gray & Christmas. "This is where those people who have the hardest time finding jobs get a chance. Companies need people to do the work, the most-skilled, highest performers are taken, so they take chances."

He points out that long-term unemployment has fallen by 1.2 million in the last 12 months and thinks job gains will only accelerate. And, he adds, anyone counted as "long-term unemployed" is at least looking for work.

Yet Challenger notes that more jobs were lost in the Great Recession than were created from June 2003 to January 2008. He advocates tax breaks for companies that offer targeted worker training and development. Bigger tax breaks might be offered for firms that hire the underemployed.

Van Horn thinks changes may have to come from firms and workers. Many employers have lots of reasons to hire only part-time workers, he pointed out, such as a lean payroll and avoiding ObamaCare penalties.
They must weigh that against negatives such as higher turnover, but would-be workers have their own incentives, Van Horn added.

McCarty is thinking a lot about those working "beneath their station." They may take a job that's not ideal, only to find it's too hard to continue job-searching, he said. He also thinks the job market is becoming even more driven by "who you know," a reality that favors the already — or at least recently — employed.

"I feel pretty hopeful about the whole thing but the nature of the job search has changed," he said.Mike McCarty has watched people job-search for 25 years. Taser (TASR) announced an array of stun-gun and camera orders Monday from police departments across North America, adding to Wall Street views that the company could be the top law-enforcement tech supplier.
Oppenheimer began coverage of the stock with an outperform rating, a 28 price target, and above-consensus earnings forecasts for 2015 and 2016.

"The company has emerged as one of the leading players in the potentially rapid growing space of on-officer body cameras and digital evidence management," analyst Andrew Uerkwitz wrote in a note. "We believe Taser's widespread success in (conducted electrical weapons) has paved the way to make it the leading technology provider to law enforcement agencies."
Shares jumped 8.7% to 26.06, the highest since January 2005.

While recent police shootings have put the focus on body cameras, demand for Taser's weapons remains high. Among the orders announced Monday, Canada's Ontario Provincial Police had the largest, with 1,879 X2 guns. Deployment of such weapons in that country is scaling up, the company said.

The Baltimore Police Department ordered 545 of the company's X26Ps smart weapons. Three international orders were booked for Taser's weapons and HD video cameras that attach to them. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey also ordered 50 X2s with Taser's Cam HD recorders.

Taser has also made a push into wearable cameras for officers. While Monday's release cited no orders for those cameras, the company last week said the Los Angeles Police Department bought 860 Taser AXON body cameras, making that city's cop unit the largest to use them. L.A. plans to have 7,000 camera-equipped officers by next year.

Those deals follow a string of orders from law enforcement in 2014 for weapons and cameras. Digital Ally (DGLY), which also makes wearable cameras for police, has seen its share of orders too. Digital Ally stock closed down 1% Monday after rising earlier.

Demands to change policing policies and technology should continue. On Monday, prosecutors said a white ex-Milwaukee police officer will not be charged for fatally shooting a black man in April. That followed nonindictments of white police officers on Staten Island, N.Y., and in Ferguson, Mo., over the killings of two black men.
The killing of two NYPD officers this past weekend has sparked a backlash against protests over the police shootings.

Due to regulatory scrutiny and Americans' changing habits, tobacco makers have had to adjust their business model.
But one thing hasn't changed — their hefty dividend payout.

Altria Group (MO) on Thursday reported Q3 earnings of 69 cents a share, up 6% from last year and a penny above views, helped by higher cigarette prices. Sales slipped 1% to $6.5 billion. The Marlboro maker's cigarette shipments declined 3%.

As the industry faces smoking bans, health concerns and other issues, Altria and the other players have been moving to electronic cigarettes and other alternatives. Altria plans to expand distribution of its MarkTen e-cigarette throughout the U.S. in Q4.
Altria in August raised its dividend to 52 cents a share, up 4 cents. That's $2.08 on an annual basis, for a yield of 4.4%, more than double the S&P 500's average 1.9%.

Philip Morris International (PM), which makes Marlboro and other brands for the international market, saw its Q3 profit dip 3% to $1.39 on a 3% increase in sales to $21.3 billion. Earnings topped views by 6 cents. In September, the tobacco maker upped its payout by 6 cents to $1.00 a share, or $4.00 for the year. That works out to a 4.5% yield. Philip Morris was spun off by parent Altria in 2008.

Lorillard's (LO) Q3 profit rose 8% to 90 cents a share, meeting views. Sales were flat at $1.8 billion. The maker of Newport cigarettes, which is being acquired by Reynolds American (RAI), said its Blu e-cigarette brand has a U.S. retail market share of nearly 30%. Its $2.46 annualized payout yields 4%.

Reynolds, whose brands include Camel and Pall Mall, topped forecasts with Q3 EPS of 95 cents, up 10% from the year-ago period. Sales rose 5% to $2.24 billion, helped by higher prices. Like Altria, cigarette sales fell 3%.

Its dividend payout is 67 cents a share, or $2.68 for the year, for a 4.3% yield. Taser International (TASR) launched a $99-a-month service called the Officer Safety Plan that is part of the Los Angeles Police Department's body camera order.The service includes Evidence.com features such as data storage and processing for use as evidence in court, along with unlimited storage and automatic upgrades to newer-model Axon cameras every 2.5 years as well as upgrades to associated Taser devices every five years.Taser CEO Rick Smith recently told IBD that L.A. planned to make the purchase, calling it "a game changer" because it's the largest city to adopt the cloud-based Evidence.com system. The service, more so than the cameras, is key to Taser."Cameras are not that interesting from an investor standpoint," Smith said. "It's a commoditized product. The Evidence.com piece is our real major advantage."Shares were up about 7% in Wednesday afternoon trading in the stock market today. Rival wearable camera maker Digital Ally (DGLY) climbed 10%. GoPro (GPRO), which also makes wearable cameras, was up 1.6%.Taser stock formed a long cup-with-handle base from the end of February to late October, crossing above an 18.76 buy point on Oct. 31.Following the L.A. order announcement Tuesday, it's about 32% above the buy point. Taser crossed above its 50-day line on Oct. 28 and is far extended above the 50-day and 200-day.Police agencies have adopted officer-worn cameras and video storage systems in the wake of a series of prominent police shootings, including lack teen Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo., in August; and Ezell Ford by two L.A. police officers on Aug. 11.L.A. will place an initial order for the first 860 Taser cameras this quarter for delivery in the first half of 2015. In all, the city plans to buy about 7,000 cameras.No financial terms were given. But based on prior contracts with law enforcement agencies, the agreement will amount to millions in added revenue for Taser over the five-year rollout period.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.

Justice: Led by the Senate chaplain, of all people, congressional staffers fan the flames of racial division by doing something that Michael Brown of Ferguson, Missouri, never did before he assaulted officer Darren Wilson.It mattered not to the congressional aides who walked off their jobs Thursday to protest the deaths of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo., and Eric Garner in New York that a police officer dies while on duty every 58 hours — or that a grand jury found that officer Darren Wilson had reason to fear becoming one of them.There they were, raising their hands in a gesture that black witnesses testifying before a grand jury said Michael Brown never made as he charged Wilson "like a football player" and after he punched Wilson and struggled for the cop's firearm.There was Senate chaplain Barry Black, standing in front of 210 staffers and a few congressmen, saying, "Forgive us when we have failed to lift our voices for those who can't speak or breathe for themselves."That was a thinly veiled reference to what Garner reportedly said as he struggled with police officers led by a black female sergeant, all unaware of his medical issues, in New York.The fact is, if neither Garner nor Brown had resisted arrest, both would be alive today.No longer able to speak or breathe for themselves are the 1,501 police officers that the National Law Enforcement Officers Memorial Fund reports have died in the line of duty in the past 10 years, an average of one every 58 hours. Over that decade, on average, have been 58,261 assaults against police officers every year, resulting in 15,658 injuries annually caused by criminal assailants who, like Brown, never put their hands up.One of those cops was Daryl Pierson, 32, of Rochester, N.Y., who was killed by Thomas Johnson III, wanted for a parole violation, as he fled from one of those routine traffic stops the likes of Al Sharpton cite as racial profiling and "driving while black."President Obama once famously said that if he had a son he would look like Trayvon Martin, the Florida teen shot and killed by neighborhood watch volunteer George Zimmerman. It is not known if he is willing to make the same claim about Johnson."These congressional staffers put in incredibly long hours, nights and weekends, to pass legislation to help people lead better lives, so I fully support them," said Rep. Elijah Cummings, D-Md., who said the protest was to show how "incredibly frustrated" they are by the Brown and Garner deaths and the "mistrust" these and other protesters have in the criminal justice system.Would that be the same criminal justice system that put Thomas Johnson III back on the streets?Cops of all colors also put in incredibly long hours, nights and weekends protecting those people striving to lead better lives. Instead of thanks, they get lectures on profiling and racial sensitivity from grandstanding politicians and Attorney General Eric Holder.Waynesboro, Va., is not Ferguson, Mo., and 45-year-old reserve police officer Kevin Quick is not Michael Brown.According to police, Quick was set upon by three siblings and a fourth man, and was carjacked, kidnapped and taken from bank to bank to withdraw money using his own debit card at gunpoint before being shot to death.Holder has taken the death penalty off the table in this case, and the four defendants will instead face the possibility of life without parole, lest they unfairly face the ultimate penalty from a mistrusted criminal justice system. Kevin Quick's death penalty cannot be revoked, a risk every cop faces every day.When a cop dies, there are no riots or protests. Just another cop funeral.

War On Cops: True to his word, Attorney General Eric Holder has released new national "anti-profiling" guidelines directing law enforcement to ignore "statistical evidence" generated by his own department.'Even if there were overall statistical evidence of differential rates of commission of certain offenses among individuals possessing particular characteristics, the affirmative use of such generalized notions by law enforcement officers in routine, spontaneous law enforcement activities is tantamount to stereotyping," and therefore punishable, Holder warned in his 12-page guidance."Even if?" Holder's acting dumb. He's fully aware such evidence exists. And it's highly relevant to proactive policing, because it shows stark differences in criminal behavior between blacks and whites.In fact, recent Justice Department reports reveal that African-Americans commit 53% of all murders, and 10 times more violent crime than whites. Young black men, more alarmingly, make up only 1% of the population but commit a whopping 27% of the nation's murders.Most of this violent crime occurs in urban areas. But now, under the new federal anti-profiling regime, law enforcement cannot target these high-crime areas if they're predominantly black or Latino. Nor can they associate ethnic gangs with "a certain ethnicity."The federal guidelines are expected to heavily influence local law enforcement.Holder this week is also briefing local police chiefs on the policy changes. He hopes that once federal agencies implement these standards, they'll set an example for local law enforcement agencies to adopt as well.Holder's also requiring federal agents to go through "de-biasing" training, something he's already mandated for several major city police departments as part of consent orders he's forced through discrimination investigations. The training, which tries to cleanse cops of "unconscious bias," has led to a phenomenon known as "de-policing" in high-crime areas.Seattle, for one, is suffering a crime wave following federally mandated police retraining. Its cops are suing Holder for forcing them to ignore crime in the hood. Downtown residents have complained to the mayor that police are no longer protecting them from thugs.New Orleans also has seen crime spike since falling under Holder's de-biasing orders.Holder says the guidance is necessary to end "racial profiling" in the wake of "recent incidents" in which black men have died in confrontations with white police officers. But neither of the cases he's referencing had anything to do with profiling.In Ferguson, Mo., police were responding to a robbery by a man described as black. In Staten Island, N.Y., police were responding to complaints from business owners that a man described as black was bootlegging cigarettes outside their stores. In both cases, the suspects died while resisting arrest.Holder wants cops to do more "community policing," which means more talking and less arresting."Good law enforcement work also requires that officers take steps to know their surroundings even before there is a specific threat," the guidance intones. "Getting to know a community and its features can be critical to building partnerships and facilitating dialogues, which can be good for communities and law enforcement alike."But that didn't work in Ferguson. According to the St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Ferguson police were known for reaching out to residents even in the violent neighborhood where Michael Brown was shot. Officers were "on a first-name basis with residents" there, and even gave "people rides home during snowstorms." The chief put patrolmen through diversity training each year.Still, Holder says it's OK to target a high-crime minority neighborhood for community outreach, just not for crime-fighting.His guidance actually urges law enforcement to "map out the features of the city within its area of responsibility in order to gain a better understanding of outreach opportunities" and obtain "information from public sources regarding population demographics, including concentrations of ethnic groups.""This activity is permissible," Holder says, failing to see the contradiction in his policy.If police back off from effectively policing high-crime areas, the law-abiding minorities under violent siege there will be hurt the most.

Racial Politics: The boy who cried wolf has more credibility than this president and his attorney general. They cried "Racism!" in Sanford, Ferguson and now Staten Island, and have been proved wrong in each case.Within minutes of jurors clearing a white NYPD cop in the death of African-American suspect Eric Garner, President Obama phoned Eric Holder, who, in turn, launched a federal investigation into perceived civil-rights violations. The probe follows those already underway in Ferguson, Mo., and Sanford, Fla.Never mind that a predominantly minority grand jury, sifting through all the evidence, found that the force used to subdue the 6-foot-3-inch, 350-pound Garner was reasonable. Or that Garner was caught on video repeatedly resisting arrest after breaking the law, though the career criminal knew the drill following 31 previous arrests. Or that cops showed no racial animus. Or that a black sergeant supervised them.Such exonerating facts have zero effect on Obama, who seems bent on seeding distrust in the U.S. justice system as part of a radical racial agenda.Hoover Institution scholar Thomas Sowell said the president "wants to spread paranoia" in the black community, adding, "What amazes me is how long it has taken so many people to see through this man."Obama asserted the Garner case "speaks to the larger issues that we've been talking about now for the last week, the last month, the last year — and, sadly, for decades — and that is the concern on the part of too many minority communities that law enforcement is not dealing with them in a fair way."Implying America remains institutionally biased against blacks is a serious charge. And it's a scurrilous one. Study after study has found no bias in the arrest, prosecution or sentencing of African-Americans.Tearing down respect for the justice system is bad enough. But it's hardly the only institution Obama has accused of structural bias. He and his race-baiting attorney general have also framed banking, education and housing, among others, as equally racist.Consider everyone they've accused of bias in the past six years: mortgage lenders, loan service companies, auto lenders, small business lenders, payday lenders, student loan companies, home insurers, investment bankers, credit card companies, branch bankers charging overdraft fees, credit reporting agencies, medical debt collectors, supermarket chains without enough stores in blighted areas, mayors and local zoning boards limiting subsidized housing, the 48 states barring felons from voting and employers using criminal and credit background checks to screen job applicants.They've even accused school principals, teachers, resource officers and curriculum directors of discriminating against black students.In this massive calumny, they've failed to cite a single example of intentional discrimination. Or ID a single victim by name. In every complaint, they've leveled ambiguous charges of "implicit" bias based on "disparate impact," a discredited theory based on raw stats which fail to control for legitimate factors explaining racial disparities. That's because they have no proof, just like in Sanford, Ferguson and Staten Island, N.Y.Yet hundreds of billions of dollars are being redistributed based on these false claims of discrimination.Worse, policies governing everything from bank lending and school discipline to hiring and credit-risk analysis are being revamped to produce the desired racial outcomes — that is, quotas — demanded by this president.Now, with the administration investigating more than 20 police departments across the country for "biased policing," the same will be done for arrest, stop and search policies in communities of color.

Ferguson: Charles Barkley could sit back and enjoy the fruits of his stellar basketball career. Instead, placing others before himself, he's telling the charlatans who pose as black leaders where they can get off.It takes guts to tell your own people hard truths, but famed power forward Sir Charles has always displayed toughness. In 1991, he got into trouble for spitting at a white New Jersey Nets fan shouting racist names at him — only for it to land on the wrong fan.No one can say Barkley is oblivious to racial bigotry. "We've always had a racial issue in this country," he told CNN on Wednesday. "And the biggest problem with it is, we never discuss race until something bad with it happens."Now his aim is true, and he's got Al Sharpton in his sights, along with the other parasites who feed on black misery, set the stage for rioting and blame every black problem on white racism while ignoring the corrosive effects of government-instigated pathologies like welfare dependency and single motherhood.With another grand jury refusing Wednesday to indict a white police officer — this one New York City's Daniel Pantaleo in the chokehold death of Eric Garner, a black man who was allegedly resisting arrest — Barkley's courageous comments couldn't be better timed.Garner's mother and son are making statements alongside Sharpton in the wake of the grand jury decision, so the same dangerous climate of possible street violence is now brewing, this time in the Big Apple.Barkley said that he won't back away from calling the looters in Ferguson, Mo., "scumbags."  "When you're looting people's property, that's what you are," he said.  "You wouldn't want people to do it to your house."He also calls it "just flat-out ridiculous" to believe that white cops purposely kill black people. "Cops are actually awesome," he declared. "You know, they're the only thing in the ghetto between this place being the wild, wild west.""We as black people, we got a lot of crooks," Barkley added. "We have to look ourself in the mirror. There's a reason they racially profile us at times. Sometimes it's wrong, but sometimes it's right. So to sit there and act like we hold no responsibility for some of this stuff, that's disingenuous."The man known in the NBA as "the Round Mound of Rebound" said that the jury in Ferguson got it right in not indicting white officer Darren Wilson in the killing of 18-year-old black robbery suspect Michael Brown.  Barkley was also sure to ruffle feathers by saying of the killing and its riotous aftermath: "We don't have to have Al Sharpton go there.""We have the same sad sack of black characters" after every controversial incident in the black community involving race, Barkley said. Instead, he contended, "We need some strong black men in St. Louis to stand up and say, 'Hey, let's handle this situation.'"Barkley is the opposite of Sharpton. When black well-being improves, Sharpton loses relevance — and revenues. Barkley, on the other hand, has nothing to gain and everything to lose from speaking tough truths.He could spend the rest of his life charging fans for autographs and making endorsements; instead, he offers real leadership and risks making himself unpopular and unjustly targeted for ridicule by Sharpton and the rest of the phony leaders and their blind followers.It takes a black sports icon to exercise the leadership that should be coming from the first black president.

Crime: A pointless national task force on Ferguson, Mo., won't reverse an unassailable grand jury decision on officer Darren Wilson. The "solvable problem" that President Obama says "Ferguson laid bare" isn't the problem.When it comes to the challenges of urban crime, law enforcement, racial friction and seemingly intractable poverty, one objective should top the list for our elected leaders: Keep innocents who live and work in places like Ferguson, most of whom are black, safe from criminals, most of whom are black.To that way of thinking, a youth who steals cigarillos from a convenience store, then roughs up the clerk, is the enemy of the community — not the police officer who, sadly, ends up shooting him.But that's not the mindset of this president. To him, the killing of Michael Brown "laid bare" an age-old national problem: "a simmering distrust that exists between too many police departments and too many communities of color."And so now "a task force" will not only "reach out and listen to law enforcement and community activists and other stakeholders, but report to me specifically in 90 days with concrete recommendations" on how "we at the federal level" can "work with the state and local communities" to get "best practices for communities where law enforcement and neighborhoods are working well together ... institutionalized."Similarly, Democratic Party adviser Donna Brazile says: "we need a national commission on justice. One that is more than a fact-finding commission," and which would be modeled on Bishop Tutu's South African "Truth and Reconciliation Commission" — of which Tutu said, "forgiveness also requires acknowledgment on the part of the perpetrator that they have committed an offense."But Wilson did not commit any offense to acknowledge; Brown did.What exactly will such task forces and commissions end up doing? Reversing legal decisions like that of the true fact-finders: Ferguson's ultra-thorough grand jurors, whose evidence included six black eyewitnesses who helped exonerate Officer Wilson?Will the federal government eventually veto local criminal-justice decisions in hopes of preventing Ferguson-like riots? That would trample the rule of law in America.If you listen to the president's latest long-winded speech — Monday's was 1,450 words — this great national problem exposed by Ferguson is all about "people feeling marginalized and distrustful." Feelings?The president even concedes that "there have been commissions before, there have been task forces, there have been conversations, and nothing happens."That about says it all.

Taser International (TASR) and Digital Ally (DGLY), both major manufacturers of body-mounted video cameras, could benefit from the Obama administration's actions to provide federal funding for body-worn cameras for police officers.

In an announcement Monday by the White House, President Barack Obama proposed an executive order allotting $75 million over three years to help law enforcement agencies purchase 50,000 body-worn cameras.
The total $263 million program would provide a 50% match to law enforcement agencies in states and localities that purchase body-worn cameras and training on their use.
Obama's actions come in the wake of civil unrest after a grand jury decided not to indict an officer who fatally shot an unarmed black teenage robbery suspect in Ferguson, Mo.

"Recent unrest in Ferguson, Missouri, and around the country have highlighted the importance of strong, collaborative relationships between local police and the communities they protect," a White House statement said. "The initiative as a whole will help the federal government efforts to be a full partner with state and local law enforcement agencies in order to build and sustain trust between communities and those who serve and protect these communities."

The money would also be used for police training to ensure law enforcement personnel receive proper training in how to use the equipment while protecting citizens' civil liberties, the statement said.
Taser International stock rose almost 3% to 22.09, nearly a 10-year high. Shares edged up about 1% in late trading. Taser hit an all-time high of 33.45 in December 2004.

Taser stock jumped last week after the Winston-Salem Police Department ordered 623 more of the company's Axon body cameras for its officers, bringing its total purchase to 916, enabling the department to outfit its entire force with the cameras.
Last month, the San Francisco Police Department ordered 160 Axon cameras, while the Los Angeles police force recently announced plans to buy the officer-worn cameras.

Rival body-camera maker Digital Ally stock fell nearly 4% to close at 12.87, but then jumped to 13.90 in late trading. Digital Ally stock closed Monday down more than 61% from an all-time high of 33.59 in early September.
Use of officer-worn body cameras has risen sharply this year as law enforcement moves to document field encounters that sometimes have tragic consequences.
GoPro (GPRO), an action-camera maker for the consumer market that's on the IBD 50 list of top-rated stocks, fell nearly 6% to 73.50 on Monday.

Crime: By rolling the red carpet out for black "leader" Al Sharpton, President Obama spits in the eye of every police officer — white, black or whatever. A federal war on police begins.Scholar Heather MacDonald of the Manhattan Institute's City Journal charges that "President Obama betrayed the nation" and "perverted his role as the leader of all Americans and as the country's most visible symbol of the primacy of the law" in his comments after a grand jury found no evidence of wrongdoing by white police officer Darren Wilson in the shooting of black suspect Michael Brown."The testimony of a half-dozen black observers at the scene demolished the early incendiary reports that Wilson attacked Brown in cold blood and shot Brown in his back when his hands were up," MacDonald noted, with witnesses claiming brutality by Wilson exposed as inconsistent and finding themselves "contradicted by the physical evidence and by other witnesses, who corroborated Wilson's testimony that Brown had attacked him and had tried to grab his gun."Obama should have praised the grand jury's conclusion, coming after a thorough examination of all the evidence, and affirmed the integrity of America's criminal justice system.  But like the violent, looting protesters in Ferguson, Mo., our president is uninterested in the truth.No wonder a demagogue who personifies politicized lies like Al Sharpton is welcomed into the White House — not by any means for the first time — to advise Obama.Too many have forgotten who Sharpton is.  He came to fame peddling the elaborate Tawana Brawley hoax in upstate New York in 1987, in which a black teen fabricated the claim she was gang-raped by a white policeman, a local white prosecutor and four other white men, her clothes torn and burned, her body smeared with excrement, and "KKK" and the N-word and "bitch" written on her torso with a a charcoal-like substance.After a grand jury spent seven months confirming it was all a lie, Sharpton and Brawley were successfully sued for slander to the tune of hundreds of thousands of dollars.Sharpton has never been elected dog catcher anywhere. But according to CBS' "60 Minutes," he is "a trusted White House adviser who has become the president's go-to black leader, campaigning around the country for President Obama and his agenda."  Obama has called him "the voice of the voiceless and a champion for the downtrodden."In August, the IBD/TIPP Poll found 64% of the public with an unfavorable opinion of Sharpton; only 29% had a favorable view.  A Zogby poll commissioned last year by Black Entertainment Television founder Robert L. Johnson found that while one in four blacks considered Sharpton to be their voice, significantly more — 40% of blacks — said no one speaks for them.Undoubtedly a great many of those black Americans are sick of self-promoting parasites like Sharpton who exist on black violence and economic misery.  Instead of exercising real leadership of their community — which would mean confronting the long-term epidemic of black-on-black crime whose casualties number in the thousands every year — Sharpton blames the cops who risk their lives saving countless black lives in high-crime neighborhoods.Now Obama reportedly plans to spend hundreds of millions of dollars to force police to wear video cameras on their persons and "demilitarize" law enforcement. In other words, further endangering our men and women in blue.A president who promised to unite America has found yet another way of dividing it.

Starting Over: A black woman who sold cake at flea markets to save enough money to open her own shop saw it vandalized and looted by those who claim white cops are the major problem facing black America.Natalie Dubose's Ferguson, Mo., business, Cakes & More, barely survived the arson, rioting and looting that followed a grand jury's not indicting officer Darren Wilson in the shooting of Michael Brown. Her tears then turned to sweat as she struggled to fill Thanksgiving cake orders just as she labored to build her business from the ground up.President Obama once famously told people such as Dubose that she "didn't build that," and that she was the mere beneficiary of a benevolent government and its social engineering.Well, she did build that, and no one from the government helped her bake her cakes or rebuild her business after rioters smashed one of two large windows and damaged her baking equipment."If I can't open my doors in the morning, I can't feed my kids in the evening," Dubois told CNN over the weekend and before the Monday verdict and the subsequent rioting."Just don't burn my shop down, don't destroy it," she pleaded before looters decided to "protest" the grand jury's decision not to indict Wilson, who confronted Brown after a strong-armed robbery of Ferguson Market & Liquors.Ferguson Market & Liquors was again a target Monday night as looters, whom some have dubbed undocumented shoppers in a bit of gallows humor, ran in and out, knocking over a Fox News camera in the process as they clutched pilfered bottles of vodka and bourbon, trophies of their fight against social injustice and the perceived bigotry of their oppressors.Dubose opened her shop in June, shortly before Brown was shot in August. The riots after the shooting almost shut down her fledgling business. For two weeks after the shooting, reports the Washington Post, not a single customer entered her shop.This time, as she returned to board up her shop and see what she could do, white racist America came to her aid with two GoFundMe campaigns raising more than $90,000 to help Dubose repair her shop.Celebrities Patricia Heaton and Brandi Glanville urged their Twitter followers to help and they did. It's not known whether Al Sharpton contributed, or even knows who Natalie Dubose is."I am a single mom, a mother of two," Dubose told CNN Money. "This is everything I own; I can't walk away from it. I just got to start up and start baking again."Dubose added: "We have orders to go out for Thanksgiving. I can't tell the people — I won't tell the people — that I'm canceling."About 25 Ferguson businesses were burned Monday night, most of them minority-owned. They were started in the face of the real problems facing blacks in America — rising illegitimacy, crime, poverty and lack of education, and a war on poverty that succeeded only in destroying the black family as it subsidized a culture of dependency on government.Dubose refused to be a victim of crime or culture and still refuses, even as those from President Obama and Attorney General Eric Holder to Jesse Jackson and Sharpton seek to stoke the flames of racial division and the culture of victimhood.Dubose is a real leader of the black community, someone who is the rightful heir of the marchers on that bridge in Selma, Ala.Like Martin Luther King, she has a dream too.If you're ever in Ferguson, Mo., there's a cake shop we'd like to recommend.

Smith & Wesson's stock got a lift early Wednesday after the company announced a $130 million all-cash bid for privately held Battenfeld Technologies, a hunting and shooting accessories provider.Smith & Wesson (SWHC) — which is expected to disclose soft second-quarter earnings after the market closes on Thursday, Dec. 4 — says that the acquisition will beef up its accessories business.CEO James Debney said that the purchase "allows us to move more strongly into the hunting vertical as well as establish a strong platform for growth in our existing firearm accessories business, which has been a small but highly profitable part of our company."Based in a 145,000-square-foot facility in Columbia, Mo., Battenfeld makes shooting, reloading, gunsmithing and gun cleaning supplies under several brands.Battenfeld CEO Jim Gianladis will stay on as president of the accessories unit, reporting directly to Debney.Smith & Wesson says that it expects the deal to close in mid- to late December and that the acquisition will be accretive to its earnings in about a year.The No. 2 U.S. firearms maker by revenue, behind archrival Sturm Ruger (RGR), could use a lift.Smith & Wesson enjoyed double-digit quarterly sales growth in recent years, but it turned to shrinking sales the last two quarters in a row amid a firearms glut. Its stock price has plunged about 44% since June 11, including Wednesday's gain. By late afternoon, shares were up 1.4% in the stock market today.Smith & Wesson is forecast to report Q3 earnings of 7 cents per share, far below the 28-cent profit that it posted a year ago. President Obama and his race-baiting henchmen Eric Holder and Al Sharpton are now 0-2. Just when they thought they had a flash point for a race war in Ferguson, Mo., after the one manufactured in Sanford, Fla., fizzled, the forensic evidence snuffs it out.They've been caught, once again, crying wolf about discrimination in another white-on-black shooting. You'd think they'd stop demagoguing, but they're only doubling down."Communities of color aren't just making these problems up," Obama insisted, blaming their trouble with law enforcement on "the legacy of racial discrimination" and even claiming their rioting is "an understandable reaction."But multiracial jurors don't buy it and neither does a public growing weary of a black president making excuses for black criminality.African-Americans still represent less than 13% of the population but now commit an astounding 53% of the nation's murders. In urban centers like St. Louis, as well as Chicago and New York, their share of homicides is even higher, based on Holder's own data.Still, Obama uses Michael Brown as a poster boy for "much-needed criminal justice reform," including diversifying local police forces, training cops in ethnic sensitivity and banning criminal profiling. He's planning prejudice powwows, with federal funding tied to compliance with reforms."I have instructed Attorney General Holder not just to investigate what happened in Ferguson," he announced last week in Chicago, "but also identify specific steps we can take ... to make sure that law enforcement is fair and is being applied equally," as if it isn't already.This is the same fair-minded attorney general who prejudged the Brown shooting as a racist execution, even likening it to the 1955 murder of Emmett Till. "Reform" also includes Holder's overseeing the early prison release of some 50,000 crack felons next year.Blaming black crime on racism does nothing to solve the problem. It only keeps the furnaces of hate burning in the hood and encourages young black men to use race as a pretext to resort to lives of crime. And tragically, it leads more to commit suicide by gang or cop.To portray Brown as a civil-rights martyr is the height of dishonesty. The record now shows he was a wannabe gangsta, victim only of the welfare plantation that left him fatherless and living in subsidized housing where he idled away in a pot-smoking haze.His partner in crime, Dorian Johnson, shocked grand jurors by casually testifying he smokes dope first thing in the morning. The 22-year-old baby daddy doesn't get up and get dressed for work. No, he gets up and starts rolling blunt."I smoke marijuana in my mornings when I start my day off," the jobless Johnson boasted, adding he and Brown were on a quest to score some "rillos," or cigarillos.Like too many young black men, he and Brown would cut open the slim cigars, empty out the tobacco and replace it with weed, turning them into oversized joints.This ambition-robbing daily habit led to the Ferguson tragedy. Smoking blunt was all they cared about — get up, get "rillos," get back, roll blunt and get high another wasted day — even if it meant robbing a convenience store.And a cop out doing his job got in the way of that pathetic goal.There's no "racial divide," as the race baiters claim. But there is a cultural divide, and it only widens with each round of apologia from black leaders who stand guilty of black-on-black political crimes. Brown was immersed in that culture, and it cost him his life.Brown wasn't stopped because he "was a big, black, scary man," as the racial arsonists like to say; he was stopped because he was a big bully. And he was shot because he was an attempted cop killer.Maybe Brown didn't deserve to die, but given his threatening actions, he was certainly asking to. Both a police sergeant and FBI agent testified that Ferguson police officer Darren Wilson told them contemporaneously that Brown reached into his waistband just before he charged him, a motion that made Wilson think Brown might be pulling out a weapon. Witnesses say Brown ignored repeated orders to stop.White cop or black cop, the result would have been the same: justifiable homicide.One of the Brown family lawyers, in excusing Michael's strong-arm robbery, said it's not like he gave the store clerk "a beat down." The culture of violence in the black community is so pervasive that black lawyers reason like thugs.Johnson, who's still lying about the shooting, nonetheless confirmed to jurors that he and his pal Brown had an attitude that fateful morning, daring cops to bust them as they jaywalked with their stolen loot. Even now, he doesn't see anything wrong with such behavior. Instead of shunning this perjurious punk, the black community has embraced him.Obama is wrong: Racial discrimination isn't the issue behind Ferguson, not even remotely. It's black criminality and its enablement.Rather than feeding into street paranoia about bigoted cops, a responsible leader would educate the black community in the same basic rules of conduct every white person must follow when interacting with police. Sperry, formerly IBD Washington bureau chief, is author of "The Great American Bank Robbery," which exposes the racial politics behind the housing crisis.

Leadership: In ways possible for no one else, a black president and a black attorney general could have quelled the latest violence in Ferguson, Mo. Instead, they invited mayhem.Clay Risen, author of "A Nation in Flames: America in the Wake of the King Assassination," wrote in Smithsonian magazine that the 1968 Martin Luther King riots forced President Johnson to realize "he had naively hoped that a massive assault of federal spending would relieve conditions in the ghetto overnight.""When 125 cities erupted over one weekend, he had to confront the fact that nothing he had done seemed to have had an effect."Still, imagine if it had been a black president, once a state senator from Chicago's South Side, who had said:"I ask every citizen to reject the blind violence that has struck Dr. King, who lived by nonviolence."LBJ was soon forced to admit he was "not getting through." Regrettably, some of what President Obama said after a grand jury declined to indict the white police officer who shot and killed Michael Brown did get through.Obama called anger "an understandable reaction" and warned police not to work "against the community." This supposed uniter said, "A deep distrust exists between law enforcement and communities of color. Some of this is the result of the legacy of racial discrimination in this country."Calling for "much-needed criminal justice reform," Obama said, "Communities of color aren't just making these problems up," "The law too often feels as if it is being applied in discriminatory fashion" and "These are real issues, and we have to lift them up and not deny them or try to tamp them down."According to the president, "Those who are only interested in focusing on the violence and just want the problem to go away need to recognize that we do have work to do here, and we shouldn't try to paper it over."Using his statement to promote discredited liberal policies dilutes its accompanying admonitions against "throwing bottles" and "smashing car windows," because he just told those committing the "blind violence" LBJ condemned that their rioting is actually rational — their anger is "an understandable reaction."America's first black attorney general, Eric Holder, meanwhile mulls federal charges against officer Darren Wilson, in spite of the multiracial grand jury's decision.What could Obama and Holder have done as the first black president and attorney general to protect lives and livelihoods, mostly black? Travelled to Ferguson and told one and all to respect a lawful grand jury finding.The follow-up could have been the words of former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani, who said, "The first minute you break a window, you are put in handcuffs" — whatever your race.

Media Bias: The lens through which the dominant media present events in Ferguson, Mo., projects a distorted, hall-of-mirrors image to the public. Report reality, not alternate reality filtered through ideology.NBC's idea of legal commentary Tuesday on the Michael Brown killing was to have Hollywood lawyer Gloria Allred's daughter tell viewers that "charging" (Officer Darren Wilson's straightforward description of how Brown attacked him) is "a racially tinged offensive word."What other "racist" words must we purge from the English language? Stabbing? Looting? Raping? Burglary? The Washington Bullets basketball team had to change its name because so many bullets were flying in the nation's capital.CBS interviewed Brown's parents about Wilson's account of Brown's death, and his mother assured us, unchallenged, that "he would never provoke anyone to do anything to him and he wouldn't do anything to anybody" — so don't believe that surveillance video that clearly shows Brown stealing cigars and assaulting a clerk at a convenience store, just minutes before his violent encounter with Wilson.Announcing the grand jury's not-to-indict decision at night was obviously an attempt to protect life, letting innocent residents get home after work. But Rosie O'Donnell, resident intellectual on ABC's "The View," called it "a calculated decision in order to incite people."Sociologist Michael Eric Dyson on MSNBC said Wilson shot Brown not in self-defense, but because as a white "you infantilize yourself" and view a black male as "the demonization of black masculinity."Ex-Washington Post blogger Ezra Klein calls Wilson's account "unbelievable" because why would "an 18-year-old kid headed to college ... refuse to move from the middle of the street to the sidewalk?" Or "curse out a police officer?" Because, "while he might have been stoned, this isn't how stoned people act."Klein has to get out more."The venal, incompetent mainstream media has already convinced millions of people that they just know Darren Wilson is guilty and that the whole justice system is racist and corrupt for refusing to throw him in jail for the rest of his life," Federalist senior writer Robert Tracinski wrote.The media's "early reports were very clear that Michael Brown was a good, kind-hearted young man bound for college, that the shooting was totally unprovoked, that he was shot multiple times in the back, that he was executed in cold blood," he added. "Then the evidence . .. knocked down each of these claims one by one."Ironically, all this media distortion happens in spite of multiple recent street assaults of TV news crews, showing it is arguably more dangerous to be on the scene covering Ferguson than reporting from the Islamic State.Instead of portraying a thug as victim, and violent mobs as the righteous oppressed masses, the establishment media ought to stop peddling their leftist ideological delusions and get back to what they claim their business is: reporting facts, not fantasies.

Law Enforcement: Despite a grand jury's exoneration of officer Darren Wilson after hearing all the evidence and testimony from key black witnesses, the attorney general pursues his vendetta. This is 2014, sir, not 1964.The lesson drawn from the grand jury decision in the shooting of Michael Brown is that if young blacks don't want to be shot by a police officer of any color, then don't rob a convenience store and don't wrestle that officer for his gun.It is a lesson lost on Attorney General Eric Holder, who plays with a deck that has 52 race cards in it and who thinks every police department is run by the descendants of Bull Connor.Despite the fact that a grand jury didn't see enough evidence to indict Wilson, Holder has announced that the federal investigation of the Brown shooting will continue, even though he has seen the same forensic evidence and witness testimony that the grand jury saw. There isn't a separate set of facts to be found.In a matter-of-fact presentation after the grand jury declined to indict Wilson, St. Louis County prosecutor Bob McCulloch laid out the evidence.He said that Brown, after a strong-arm robbery of a convenience store, was confronted by Wilson, who was aware of the robbery. Brown matched a description of the suspect.Multiple black witnesses testified to a struggle as Brown punched Wilson and struggled with him for his gun. Shots fired in the car were consistent with the gunpowder residue on Brown's thumb.Witnesses also testified that Brown later ran toward Wilson in "full charge," not with his hands up, but with them tucked in his waistband. Wilson had no way of knowing that Brown, who had not been frisked, was not armed.Once you assault a police officer, everything that happens after that is on you. It was in fear for his life that Wilson shot the raging, 6-foot-4-inch, 289-pound man-child who had just rushed him. Which part of that does Holder dispute or not understand? If Brown had succeeded in the attack described by Wilson and witnesses, we might have one more dead cop and might not be having this conversation.One of the hidden ironies here is that McCulloch, who presented all the evidence and testimony available to the Ferguson grand jury along with the five possible options for an indictment of Wilson, was a member of the 2008 Obama Missouri Truth Squad.According to a September 2008 CBS St. Louis affiliate report, this offshoot of the Obama campaign was "asking Missouri law enforcement to target anyone who lies or runs a misleading television ad during the presidential campaign."McCulloch, now accused of being the tip of the spear for a racist police state, spent 2008 trying to get Obama elected as the first African-American president of the United States. He is no white supremacist with police dogs and fire hoses.Last year, 76 police officers were killed in the line of duty, and we doubt Holder could name one of them without looking it up. This statistic includes shootings in Chicago, where "communities of color" see blacks killing blacks at an appalling rate that fails to spark administration concern or action.The Ferguson, Mo., of 2014 is not the Selma, Ala., of 1965, where on March 7 of that year some 600 civil-rights marchers were met by state troopers who attacked them with dogs, billy clubs and tear gas. This is not the Jim Crow era, and Michael Brown was not marching for civil rights as he walked away from the convenience store that officials say he had just robbed, clutching stolen cigars.If Holder has found a different set of facts that contradicts those that have been established, he should let everyone know.If not, he needs to call off his vendetta.

Ford's (F) 2015 F-150 has been named Kelley Blue Book's Best Overall Buy of 2015, the auto valuation company announced Monday, citing the new pickup's lighter aluminum body, fuel efficiency and competitive price.
The award marks a potential victory for the automaker, which has placed a huge bet on the new F-150, considered Ford's flagship automobile. The 2015 truck is set to debut next month.

The company spent weeks this year overhauling its Dearborn, Mich., truck plant to produce the new model, at the expense of truck sales. Ford's Kansas City, Mo.-area plant will temporarily halt operations next year for similar renovations.
Shares rose 1.5% to 15.36 in the stock market today..

The truck "stands out for its breakthrough aluminum body, a weight-saving strategy that enables its turbocharged Ecoboost engines — another breakthrough — to be even more effective and impressive," Kelley Blue Book said in a press release announcing its first-ever Best Buy Awards.
"The fact that all this advanced technology is offered on a price-competitive basis with others in the hotly contested pickup truck class sealed the F-150's win as this year's Overall Best Buy."
The manufacturer suggested retail price for the F-150 ranges from $25,420 to $50,960, according to Ford's web site
Honda's (HMC) 2015 Civic and Accord took the awards for best small car and mid-size car, respectively. General Motors' (GM) Chevy Volt topped in the Electric/Hybrid category.

Stocks opened on firm footing Tuesday, aided by a November leap in confidence among homebuilders.
The Nasdaq popped 0.7%. The S&P 500 climbed 0.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average edged up 0.2%.
Volume started evenly mixed in the stock market today , up 5% on the NYSE and down 5% on the Nasdaq, compared to trade at the same time Monday.

Builder confidence surged in November, with the National Association of Home Builders' Housing Market Index jumping to 58. That was up from October's 54 reading and well above expectations for a 55 tally. "Low interest rates, affordable home prices and solid job creation are contributing to a steady housing recovery," the group said in a statement.
Retail stocks were under pressure at the start of trade, with Urban Outfitters (URBN), Staples (SPLS), TJX (TJX) and Lowe's (LOW) posting the deepest losses among S&P 500 stocks.

Solar and electrical utility mashup SunEdison (SUNE) sparked 22% higher. The St. Peters, Mo.-based company announced it was moving into wind energy, paying $2.4 billion to acquire privately held First Wind. The company raised its 2015 project installation guidance by about 28%, to between 2.1 and 2.3 gigawatts, based on the deal.
SunEdison shares had pulled back sharply along with most energy stocks as oil prices started to fall back in July. The stock is still about 20% below its July high.
Three IBD 50 stocks grabbed gains of 3% or more at the open.

Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) jumped after announcing regulatory agencies in the U.S. and Canada had approved a saline breast implant developed with Ideal Implant. The stock is back above key levels of support as it climbs the right side of a nine-month consolidation.
Video chipmaker Ambarella (AMBA) leapt 4% in strong trade. The gain put the stock at a fresh high, and it was still extended after its October rebound from 10-week support.

SunEdison (SUNE) and TerraForm Power announced late Monday a deal to pay up to $2.4 billion to acquire wind energy company First Wind, sending shares of SunEdison and TerraForm Power soaring on Tuesday.
SunEdison stock was up 24% in midday trading in the stock market today, near 20.50. TerraForm Power (TERP) stock was up 29%, at a four-month high above 33.

St. Peters, Mo.-based SunEdison develops and operates utility-scale solar power plants and installs solar systems. It created TerraForm Power in July as a "yieldco" to own and operate solar projects that create steady revenue and pay out dividends, a strategy aimed at attracting investors and generating capital to build more projects.

"With the purchase, SunEdison acquires the leading independent wind development and asset management company and becomes the leading global renewable energy development company," SunEdison said in its news release.
Boston-based First Wind builds projects in the Northeast, West and Hawaii.

Based on the anticipated impact of the deal, SunEdison raised its 2015 installation guidance to 2.1-2.3 gigawatts from 1.6-1.8 GW, the company said in a news release. One gigawatt can provide energy for up to 750,000 homes.
SunEdison and TerraForm Power said they will pay $1.9 billion initially and $510 million in payments to follow if First Wind completes certain projects. They expect to close to deal in Q1 2015.

TerraForm Power said it would acquire 521 megawatts of operating wind and solar power plants in the deal. TerraForm Power raised its 2015 dividend guidance to $1.30 per share, a 44% increase over its current 90-cent dividend rate.
TerraForm Power's generation capacity will increase by more than 50% as a result of the acquisition, the company said.

The acquisition comes after SunEdison on Wednesday announced a joint agreement with Aboitiz Renewables, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Aboitiz Power, to explore and develop up to 300 MW of utility-scale solar power generation projects in the Philippines over the next three years.

Separately, Chinese solar-panel maker JA Solar Holdings (JASO) early Tuesday reported that Q3 revenue jumped 72% to 3 billion yuan, or roughly $492.2 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected $425.25 million.

JA Solar reported earnings excluding items of 1.31 million yuan per American depositary share, or 21 cents, compared with a loss of 2.24 million yuan, or 36 cents, a year earlier. Analysts had expected EPS ex items of 18 cents.
JA Solar stock was up 4%, near 8, in morning trading Tuesday.

JA Solar said it expects to ship 850-900 MW of cells and modules in Q4, up 8% to 15% from Q3. Justice: Eric Holder, who dropped the New Black Panther case and almost
had a defender of cop-killer Mumia abu-Jamal as an assistant, takes the

death penalty off the table for four alleged Virginia cop-killers.The National Guard has not been called up, Al Sharpton has not made an appearance, and neither have 40 FBI agents been dispatched to ensure the convictions of the four gang members who allegedly murdered a Virginia police officer.Nor will there be riots and looting if they are acquitted.When cops are the victims instead of the accused, a different standard of social justice seems to apply.Waynesboro, Va., is not Ferguson, Mo., and 45-year-old reserve Virginia police officer Kevin Quick is not Michael Brown, shot and killed by Ferguson officer Darren Wilson.In February, officer Quick never made it after he texted his girlfriend that he was on his way to see her.According to police, Quick was set upon by three siblings and a fourth man, and was carjacked, kidnapped and taken from bank to bank to withdraw money using his own debit card at gunpoint before being shot to death.His body was found in a wooded area in Goochland County six days later.Siblings Daniel Mathis, Shantai Shelton and Mersadies Shelton have been charged along with a fourth man, Kweli Uhuru, in a federal indictment that lists them as members of a street gang called the "99 Goon Syndicate," an offshoot of the infamous "Bloods" gang, and allegedly committed the murder to climb in the gang ranks.The alleged killers now await trial, which is currently set for May 4, 2015.Federal prosecutors say that U.S. Attorney General Eric Holder has taken the death penalty off the table in this case and that the four co-defendants will instead face the possibility of life without parole.No official reason has been given in this case of premeditated murder. But we suspect the reasons include Holder's opposition to the death penalty and his sharing of the belief that the death penalty in particular and the justice system in general are skewed against minority defendants such as these four accused.Fox News reports that of the 1,236 death penalty cases brought before Holder's DOJ through 2013, only 27 have been approved for the death penalty.After the botched execution of convicted killer Clayton Lockett in April, who reportedly writhed in pain before dying of a heart attack after his lethal injection, President Obama tasked Holder with a national review of the death penalty."Racial bias. Uneven application of the death penalty. Situations in which there were individuals on death row who later on were discovered to be innocent ...
