Sprint and T-Mobile shareholders punished both stocks on Wednesday after merger talks between the two wireless carriers ended, but Dish Network rose as its CEO demurred on any takeover bid.Struggling Sprint (S) halted its pursuit of T-Mobile US (TMUS), the industry's comeback kid, after concluding that a deal would not win regulatory approval. Federal Communications Commission Chairman Tom Wheeler praised Sprint's decision. U.S regulators prefer a national market with at least four players, including leaders Verizon Communications (VZ) and AT&T (T), rather than three.Besides announcing that it wouldn't pursue T-Mobile any longer, Japan's SoftBank, which owns 80% of Sprint, replaced Sprint CEO Dan Hesse with Marcelo Claure, the former CEO of wireless phone distributor Brightstar.Sprint stock plunged 19%, while T-Mobile stock fell 8.4%. Germany's Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY), which owns 67% of "Uncarrier"-branded T-Mobile, saw its U.S. shares slip 2.7%. SoftBank's stock tumbled 3.5% in Japan.Analysts see Dish Network (DISH); France's Iliad, which has made an offer; America Movil (AMX); and No. 1 cable TV firm Comcast (CMCSA) as potential buyers of T-Mobile, which has gained market share thanks to its aggressive marketing.Despite earlier statements of interest, Dish Network Chairman Charlie Ergen was cautious on the satellite broadcaster's earnings conference call early Wednesday."It's not a surprise that Sprint is walking away from T-Mo. Regulatory officials sent clear messages," Ergen said. "Obviously, we need to re-look at things based on what's happened on the M&A side the last 24 hours."The No. 1 U.S. satellite TV broadcaster, DirecTV Group (DTV), agreed in May to be purchased by AT&T."Obviously the AT&T-DirecTV deal probably lessened some optionality that we had. The Sprint announcement probably increases some optionality," Ergen said.In May, Ergen said that if Sprint and T-Mobile didn't merge, then he would be interested in T-Mobile. And last November, Ergen said that buying T-Mobile was still "on the table" despite Sprint's interest.Ergen has touted mobile video services as the satellite-TV firm's next growth engine as its core business matures.For Q2, Dish reported fewer video subscriber losses than expected but turned in a financially mixed quarter, with EPS light and revenue in line with estimates. Dish said that it lost 44,000 subscribers in Q2, compared with 78,000 in the year-earlier quarter. Analysts had expected a loss of 77,000 subscribers. Dish had 14.05 million customers as of June 30.Ergen Controls Dish VotingErgen, who holds nearly 90% of Dish's voting power, has had wireless setbacks. At one time, Dish pursued MetroPCS Communications, a regional wireless carrier eventually acquired by T-Mobile. Last year, Dish lost takeover battles for Sprint and Clearwire to SoftBank.Federal regulators in 2012 granted Dish a waiver to use airwaves that it acquired from two bankrupt satellite companies for 4G wireless service, as long as Dish builds out a network. To do that, Dish needs to find a wireless partner or to make an acquisition.Sprint — which will likely need cash for building out its 4G network and for upcoming spectrum auctions — and T-Mobile loom as possible Dish targets or partners."With Sprint out of the way, this may finally be Dish Network's moment to bid for T-Mobile," said William Power, an analyst at R.W. Baird"Deutsche Telekom still has several exit options, the best strategically being Dish — who would bring a material amount of spectrum, a customer base, the potential for video bundling and experience in the U.S. market," Sanford C. Bernstein analyst Paul de Sa said in a research report.French telecom upstart Iliad last week made a surprise $15 billion, $33 per share bid for a controlling stake in T-Mobile. But Deutsche Telekom has said that it's not in talks with Iliad, which has been a price cutter in France.According to Reuters, Iliad is speaking with Dish and other U.S. firms to pursue a joint bid for T-Mobile. Potential partners include cable TV firms.Craig Moffett, an analyst at MoffettNathanson, is skeptical of a Dish bid for T-Mobile."Is Ergen now a buyer rather than seller?" Moffett asked in a report. "Dish's valuation assumes the company will sell its spectrum. Whether it would be accorded the same valuation (as a buyer) is unclear."Dish has more than $9 billion in cash on its balance sheet and could borrow from banks to fund a wireless deal. Analysts have pegged the value of Dish's spectrum to a wide range of $7 billion to $17 billion. It's not clear if regulators would set conditions on a sale.Moffett, on the other hand, also said that "the logic of an America Movil bid (for T-Mobile) looks very compelling."Mexico-based America Movil, controlled by Carlos Slim, operates U.S. prepaid firm TracFone. TracFone, which leases network capacity from AT&T and Verizon, has almost 26 million U.S. subscribers. AT&T in June sold its 8.27% stake in America Movil for $5.57 billion, making it more plausible that the Latin American firm might make a push into the U.S.Mobile VideoMeanwhile, AT&T's proposed acquisition of DirecTV Group could spur Comcast to bid for T-Mobile US to compete better with AT&T in mobile video services, speculates UBS analyst John Hodulik.Comcast, a one-time investor in Sprint, has touted its plans to expand public Wi-Fi networks. Comcast also has the option to lease wholesale network capacity from Verizon Wireless under the terms of a radio-spectrum sale. But Hodulik says that Comcast would be better off owning a wireless network.Comcast is seeking regulatory approval to acquire No. 2 cable firm Time Warner Cable (TWC).

Developing trust is a vital building block of any relationship, whether it's with an organization, family or marriage, says Rodger Dean Duncan, a Liberty, Mo.-based executive coach."I tell my clients that trust is the operating system of any culture," he told IBD. "You can have wonderful software programs, but if the operating system is flaky, you're going to have a lot of problems."Here's how to build that trust:• Get familiar. When Paul Hiltz took over as CEO of Mercy Hospital in Cincinnati in 2006, it was struggling financially and having problems retaining employees. Hiltz told Shawn Hunter, author of  "Out Think," that he got to know each employee and got his to-do list from their suggestions. Some ideas weren't expensive, like fixing equipment and replacing carpet."Instead of delivering edicts from on high, he asked people who had been there for 10 years," said Hunter, vice president of leadership matters at online education software provider Skillsoft. "It gave them a sense of hope and aspiration."• Be genuine. Howard Behar, former president of Starbucks' (SBUX) North America unit, once worked for a struggling company and had to fire a batch of people.He told Hunter that someone left a memo on the copier outlining the move, and employees found it. Some of his executives suggested he say the memo wasn't true. But his assistant said, "Howard, only the truth sounds like the truth."Behar came clean with employees, telling them about the firm's woes. They quickly pitched in with solutions. "Truth and transparency build trust," Hunter said.• Be clear. Talking around a topic or giving selective facts — like saying you led a project without mentioning that six others helped lead it too — causes others to lose faith in you. "Clear the fog," said Duncan, author of "Change-Friendly Leadership." "Talk to people the way you want them to talk to you."• Give useful feedback. People tend to tell people "good job" without explaining. Duncan suggests telling them what they did well, such as: They were attentive to the audience's needs and gave good examples during a presentation.• Show the way. Do what you've said you would. "Otherwise, your credibility will be eroded immediately," Hunter said. One study showed kids were likelier to share candy with others when adults did so rather than told them to do it.• Listen. Campbell Jones, chief operating officer of auto auctioneer Manheim Australia, regularly gets out of the office to meet with customers, listen to employees' issues and back them up, Hunter says. That's important.• Seek dissent. Duncan worked at Campbell Soup (CPB) years ago when Gordon McGovern was CEO. When someone argued with him, McGovern would say, "Oh, terrific, you disagree. Help me understand how you see it."Said Duncan: "You can use resistance as a springboard to dialogue."• Display the result. Show your people the effect of their work. A study found that University of Michigan students were more effective in raising scholarship money when they met the potential recipients than if they didn't know who would get the money."It gets people deeply vested in the process," Hunter said.• Emphasize the good. Duncan met a Scotland Yard expert in counterfeit currency who concentrated on what the real thing looked like. An NFL coach often stopped practice to tell a receiver what he did right. "That's a wonderful leadership principle, to focus on the behavior we want," Duncan said.

Demand will exceed supply for a third year in 2014, Morgan Stanley said in a report April 8.

Regulation: Governments from the Virginia Department of Motor Vehicles to the city of Los Angeles have ordered a legitimate business to cease operations. Is America no longer the land of free-market opportunity?Large and growing numbers of Americans have availed themselves of the services of Uber, Lyft and other businesses that compete with traditional taxicabs. These rideshare companies are finding favor because, in words of Brian Doherty writing in Reason's blog, they are "superhelpful, wonderful" and make life easier for nearly everyone.The companies use a smartphone app to pair car owners with people who need rides. Writing in USA Today, Glenn Reynolds, law professor and Instapundit blogger, said rideshare offers "the comfort of a limo service, with the convenience of a taxicab." "I get a better service," he says, and "the driver gets a job."One Lyft driver told news site RYOT last year that he's learned from customers that many use his services because they feel safer and more comfortable than they do in cabs and buses.Uber has been valued at $18 billion while Lyft said in April said it was raising $250 million in capital. Clearly, consumers and investors are smitten with the companies — but regulators, not so much.The Virginia DMV has ordered both companies to cease and desist operations. Officers in Miami-Dade County, Fla., are posing as riders so they can seize cars and fine rideshare drivers up to $2,000.Kansas City, Mo., police have ticketed drivers while New Mexico's Public Regulation Commission has voted to order Lyft to shut down operations in the state. Austin, Texas, is also citing rideshare drivers and taking their cars. Last year, Los Angeles told the companies to stop providing rides.Time magazine reports that "no fewer than 14 states have issued warnings" to the rideshare businesses.And for what? What harm are these companies doing? Why are we criminalizing people who willingly give lifts to people who need rides and allowing government to choke off golden business and work opportunities?On one level, it's hard to understand why the startup rideshare companies are drawing bureaucrats' fire. After all, the parties enter into the arrangement voluntarily: Riders glad to get where they need to go, and drivers glad to get paid for taking them there.But then, rideshare companies are operating outside bureaucrats' and politicians' sphere of control. The businesses aren't licensed. (Is that really necessary?) Drivers aren't trained. (Is there some compelling reason that they should be?) And neither are they certified. (No one would suggest that drivers should be certified to give rides to their friends and family — so why does providing rides to strangers be any different?)Governments defend fees, licenses and certification as necessary components of consumer safety. But they also benefit from the hurdles they place in front of businesses. Combine the staggering amounts of money at stake with the government-caused artificial scarcity of taxicab licenses, and the outcome is poison fruit ripe for corruption.The licenses, or medallions, required for taxicabs to operate in New York City now cost more than $1 million per vehicle. In Boston, the price is north of $600,000.Governments rake in the cash and, in return for the high fees, cab companies are protected from competition by government, which caps the number of medallions it will issue. This creates an environment in which cab owners have a strong incentive to bribe officials to obtain new licenses.The argument for government oversight falls even flatter considering that rideshare companies screen drivers, buy liability insurance, require drivers to provide their own insurance, inspect drivers' cars, insist they drive relatively new vehicles and accept feedback.Instead of punishing innovators who benefit consumers and create jobs while favoring companies that pay for government protection, policymakers should be opening up this market consistent with America's free-enterprise tradition.

George Hormel was a hard worker, but his uncle was an even harder taskmaster.
It was the early 1870s, and that uncle, Jay Decker, owned a meatpacking concern in Chicago.
George, the second of 11 children, left school at 12 to work and made his way to Jay's shop.

"My hours were long and the work exhausting. At a busy time I often worked 14 hours at a stretch," wrote Hormel in his unpublished memoir, "The Open Road." "I was young and tough, but at the day's end I tumbled into bed like a felled ox. When morning came, someone often had literally to kick me out to waken me. I often wonder how I stood that killing pace as well as I did. But I learned things working for my uncle I might otherwise never have learned so thoroughly."
That experience proved invaluable. When Hormel was 31, he opened his own meatpacking company, Geo. A. Hormel & Co., and turned it into one of the biggest in the country.

By the time he retired 36 years later, the company had annual sales of $74.6 million, according to HormelFoods.com. Along the way, he created well-loved classics, such as Spam and Dinty Moore beef stew, that generations of Americans grew up on.
Hormel Foods Corp. thrives to this day, with 2013 sales of $9 billion and a stock that's been rising 600% since 2000.
Westward
Hormel (1860-1946) was born in Buffalo, N.Y., to John and Susanna Hormel, German immigrants.
By the time he was 6, the family had moved to Toledo, Ohio, where his dad opened a tannery, according to a profile by Anita Gaul in Immigrant Entrepreneurship.

George worked in the tannery after school and on weekends and became skilled. But as the country plunged into financial depression in 1873, he left school and worked full time to help support the family.

Holly Johnson, executive director of the Hormel Historic Home, an independent nonprofit not connected to Hormel Foods, says of George striking out on his own: "It's not like he was one to sit around and play or read books. He was a hard worker; he saw his father working hard."
George worked first in construction for menial wages.
He moved on to a meat market, loading ships and the Western Railway Co. After that was the stint with Uncle Jay.

Turning 19, George wanted more money. He was making $7.50 a week (worth $180 now), less than half what skilled workers earned, wrote Gaul. So George left Chicago with a friend for Kansas City, Mo., where the boys imagined jobs would be plentiful.

In fact, it took weeks of searching before they found work. He wrote in his memoir of finally receiving an offer from a hide and wool company that he was "speechless with surprise and relief and also fright at this sudden turn of fortune."

In a Hormel Historic Home blog post, Johnson wrote, "Throughout his writing he mentions several times in his life and career when the freedom to attempt something, however risky or scary, often led to his greatest successes."

That job was short-lived. Soon George was back in Chicago, working as a traveling salesman buying animal hides. Yet he yearned for more. Mulling a question his father asked of him, "When are you going to begin working at something you can show me in 30 years?" and nursing a desire to open a business of his own, George scoped out buying opportunities.
In 1887, he found one. A customer in Austin, Minn., along Hormel's route, was selling a meat shop. George saw his chance and bought the business.

He had loftier goals than just being a butcher, Johnson told IBD: "He was disappointed that he was 27 years old and didn't have much to show for it in terms of saving or settling, so this was his chance to achieve that goal."
Hormel borrowed $500 (worth $12,600 now) from his hide employer and bought the business in partnership with another man.

The two soon had differences on how to run the business, so they dissolved the partnership. With that money, Hormel established his own packinghouse in Austin, a town in southeast Minnesota, and named it Geo. A. Hormel & Co.
The new venture was in the thick of a highly competitive industry, notes Gaul. The Big Five packers, which included names still known today such as Armour and Swift, were all based in Chicago.
They dominated the volume of business and set the technological standards for the industry.
Cold Reality

"As a small, fledging meatpacker, Hormel could not even begin to compete in terms of market share with the Big Five, particularly because he did not own any refrigerated railcars until after the turn of the century," Gaul wrote.
Meanwhile, George married an Austin native, Lillian Gleason, in 1892. Their one child, Jay, was born later that year.

Hormel knew he had to specialize in other ways, so he made a calculated decision to specialize in pork. He figured it offered the best return on investment because the entire pig's carcass could be used, unlike with other animals.
He was also devoted to quality, which, he wrote, "was our only defense against the competition we had to meet from the big packers."

Said Johnson: "He just knew that as the cost of labor and goods was going up and his competitors were opting for cheaper and less sanitary ways of doing things, he wouldn't budge on that. He credits that to his mother, who was German; he learned that lesson shining shoes on Saturdays."
Hormel expanded and opened two more meat markets in Austin, increasing the number of hogs he slaughtered from 610 in his first year to 8,666 five years later and 42,538 in his 10th year, wrote Gaul.
Nurturing Employees
Hormel was well-loved by his workers because he worked alongside them and felt personally invested in their success, notes Gaul.

Austin became bound up with the Hormel company. The firm emphasized hiring from the local community while offering opportunities for advancement. And it was one of the only meatpackers to keep workers employed year-round, rather than laying them off after the slaughter, as most did.

Geo. A. Hormel was incorporated in 1901, when it became so big that George could no longer run it as what he called "a one-man show." Sales were $710,795 in 1902 and rocketed to $5 million (worth $124 million now) in 1912, Gaul wrote. The firm was slaughtering 1 million hogs annually by 1924.
For all its growth, some technological changes, such as developing a canned ham, had been elusive.

Then Jay came marching home. The son, fresh from World War I, came up with creative ideas about marketing and packaging food and implemented them. The son was particularly interested in canned food, which was "pretty deeply entrenched" in America, said Anna Zeide, a University of Wisconsin scholar specializing in food history.

Commercial canning took off in the late 19th century and flourished during the world wars when women entered the workforce and placed a premium on convenience food, says Zeide. Hormel's canned ham launched in 1926. Dinty Moore stew and Hormel chili entered the market in 1935.
The company's greatest success, Spam, hit store shelves in 1937 and grabbed an 18% market share among canned ham products within its first year.
Spam was a bonanza for Hormel because it was made of the pork shoulder, which had been considered "a throwaway piece of meat," said Carolyn Wyman, author of "Spam: A Biography."
During World War II, contracts with the military boosted Hormel, with sales doubling from 1939 and 1942, thanks largely to Spam.

In 1927, George appointed Jay president of the company and moved with Lillian to Beverly Hills, Calif. After he died at age 85, he was buried in Austin.George Hormel was a hard worker, but his uncle was an even harder taskmaster.It was the early 1870s, and that uncle, Jay Decker, owned a meatpacking concern in Chicago.George, the second of 11 children, left school at 12 to work and made his way to Jay's shop."My hours were long and the work exhausting. At a busy time I often worked 14 hours at a stretch," wrote Hormel in his unpublished memoir, "The Open Road." "I was young and tough, but at the day's end I tumbled into bed like a felled ox. When morning came, someone often had literally to kick me out to waken me. I often wonder how I stood that killing pace as well as I did. But I learned things working for my uncle I might otherwise never have learned so thoroughly."That experience proved invaluable. When Hormel was 31, he opened his own meatpacking company, Geo. A. Hormel & Co., and turned it into one of the biggest in the country.By the time he retired 36 years later, the company had annual sales of $74.6 million, according to HormelFoods.com. Along the way, he created well-loved classics, such as Spam and Dinty Moore beef stew, that generations of Americans grew up on.Hormel Foods Corp. thrives to this day, with 2013 sales of $9 billion and a stock that's been rising 600% since 2000.WestwardHormel (1860-1946) was born in Buffalo, N.Y., to John and Susanna Hormel, German immigrants.By the time he was 6, the family had moved to Toledo, Ohio, where his dad opened a tannery, according to a profile by Anita Gaul in Immigrant Entrepreneurship.George worked in the tannery after school and on weekends and became skilled. But as the country plunged into financial depression in 1873, he left school and worked full time to help support the family.Holly Johnson, executive director of the Hormel Historic Home, an independent nonprofit not connected to Hormel Foods, says of George striking out on his own: "It's not like he was one to sit around and play or read books. He was a hard worker; he saw his father working hard."George worked first in construction for menial wages.He moved on to a meat market, loading ships and the Western Railway Co. After that was the stint with Uncle Jay.Turning 19, George wanted more money. He was making $7.50 a week (worth $180 now), less than half what skilled workers earned, wrote Gaul. So George left Chicago with a friend for Kansas City, Mo., where the boys imagined jobs would be plentiful.In fact, it took weeks of searching before they found work. He wrote in his memoir of finally receiving an offer from a hide and wool company that he was "speechless with surprise and relief and also fright at this sudden turn of fortune."In a Hormel Historic Home blog post, Johnson wrote, "Throughout his writing he mentions several times in his life and career when the freedom to attempt something, however risky or scary, often led to his greatest successes."That job was short-lived. Soon George was back in Chicago, working as a traveling salesman buying animal hides. Yet he yearned for more. Mulling a question his father asked of him, "When are you going to begin working at something you can show me in 30 years?" and nursing a desire to open a business of his own, George scoped out buying opportunities.In 1887, he found one. A customer in Austin, Minn., along Hormel's route, was selling a meat shop. George saw his chance and bought the business.He had loftier goals than just being a butcher, Johnson told IBD: "He was disappointed that he was 27 years old and didn't have much to show for it in terms of saving or settling, so this was his chance to achieve that goal."Hormel borrowed $500 (worth $12,600 now) from his hide employer and bought the business in partnership with another man.The two soon had differences on how to run the business, so they dissolved the partnership. With that money, Hormel established his own packinghouse in Austin, a town in southeast Minnesota, and named it Geo. A. Hormel & Co.The new venture was in the thick of a highly competitive industry, notes Gaul. The Big Five packers, which included names still known today such as Armour and Swift, were all based in Chicago.They dominated the volume of business and set the technological standards for the industry.Cold Reality"As a small, fledging meatpacker, Hormel could not even begin to compete in terms of market share with the Big Five, particularly because he did not own any refrigerated railcars until after the turn of the century," Gaul wrote.Meanwhile, George married an Austin native, Lillian Gleason, in 1892. Stock futures shed Thursday's premarket gains and reversed to moderate losses after mixed reports on unemployment claims and Q3 GDP growth.

Dow futures dropped 57.2 points below fair market value, down from a 44-point advance an hour earlier. Nasdaq 100 futures shed an 18-point gain and dropped 20.7 points. S&P 500 futures also reversed, trading down 6.7 points.

The stock market today received a boost from the Federal Reserve Wednesday that left the Nasdaq up 1.3% so far this week and the S&P 500 showing a 0.7% gain. Both indexes are working on what would be a fifth straight weekly advance.

More important for growth investors, small caps are having a strong week. The Russell 2000 surged 2.9% Wednesday — it's strongest session since Dec. 17, 2014. That lifted the small cap gauge clear of its 50-day moving average and put it ahead 1.1% for the week. Even so, the index remains well below its next test of resistance at its 200-day line.
The IBD 50 Index popped 1.6% on Wednesday and is easily outpacing the market with a 3.6% gain for the week.

A big day of economic news was off to a mixed start, with a preliminary estimate from the Commerce Department putting Q3 GDP growth at 1.5%, less than half of the 3.9% jump in Q2 and just below forecasts for a 1.7% increase. Price inflation also softened, with the GDP price index rising 1.2%, down from 2.1% in Q2 and a shade below views for a 1.4% advance.

Unemployment claims inched fractionally higher, to 260,000, in the week ended Oct. 24, the Labor Department reported. That was better than the uptick to 265,000 claims forecast by economists. The prior week's tally was 259,000 claims. The four-week moving average dipped to 259,250, its sixth straight decline.

Atlanta Federal Reserve Bank President Dennis Lockhart is scheduled to speak in Washington, D.C., at 9:10 a.m. ET. The National Association of Realtors reports September pending home sales data at 10 a.m.

Big oil companies got the earnings ball rolling, with Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA), Total (TOT) and ConocoPhillips (COP) all down 2% after reporting results. Oil prices backed off 1%, with West Texas Intermediate at $45.51 a barrel after surging more than 6% Wednesday.

Drug maker Pfizer (PFE) climbed 3% and Allergan (AGN) soared 11% on news reports that the two companies are exploring a possible merger. The Wall Street Journal quoted unnamed sources saying the talks were in early stages and details were unclear. Pfizer ended Wednesday up 4% for the week and less than 2% above a 34.79 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

Among the premarket session's wilder moves, identity security firm Lifelock (LOCK) soared 40% on healthy Q3 results reported late Wednesday, along with news that it had settled a Federal Trade Commission lawsuit. Digital video camera maker GoPro (GPRO) dived 18% on weaker-than-forecast Q3 sales and earnings, also reported after Wednesday's close.

Among leading stocks, O'Reilly Automotive (ORLY) jumped 3%, Tesoro (TSO) rose 2% and Ellie Mae (ELLI) was flat after their Q3 reports. O'Reilly ended Wednesday's session in buy range, less than 2% above a 258.25 buy point. Tesoro was 3% below a 105.64 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

NXP Semiconductor (NXPI) dived 13%. The Netherlands-based chip maker reported Q3 earnings up a stronger-than-expected 16%, but revenue rose less than 1% — weaker than estimates. Management expanded its stock buyback initiative to 20 million shares. NXP finished Wednesday just below its 10-week moving average, and has been working to climb the right side of a four-month consolidation.
Cavium (CAVM) took an 11% hit after reporting in-line Q3 earnings and revenue late Wednesday. The chip maker has been chopping out an uneven consolidation, and fighting to hold support, since June.

At the baseball-ancient age of 42, Satchel Paige achieved his goal of pitching in the majors.
It came at a crucial juncture.
The Cleveland Indians were in the thick of the 1948 American League pennant race and needed their old rookie to win.
When he and those '48 Indians were done, they were champions of the world.

Paige (1906-82) was that rare baseball player who, in a sport defined by statistics, transcended them. He spent most of his career in the Negro Leagues and other pro loops when record keeping was often incomplete.
What speaks louder than his stats was what sluggers said about facing Paige in exhibition games while baseball was segregated.
Cheers
"Satch was the greatest pitcher in baseball," said Red Sox hitting machine Ted Williams, as quoted in "Satchel Sez" by David Sterry and Arielle Eckstut.
The Yankee Clipper, Joe DiMaggio, said Paige was "the best and fastest pitcher I've ever faced."
Bob "Rapid Robert" Feller, who with Ol' Satch armed the '48 Indians, said "Paige was the best pitcher I ever saw."

Paige stands out as a colorful, American icon, but when it came to pitching, he had a serious message. "I ain't no clown," he said, as quoted by Larry Tye in "Satchel: The Life and Times of an American Legend." "I ain't no end man in no vaudeville show. ... I'm a baseball pitcher, and winning baseball games is serious business."
Paige helped pave the way for Jackie Robinson's integration into Major League Baseball in 1947, and in July of the next year he signed with Bill Veeck's Indians.

Paige won six critical games down the stretch for Cleveland, while fans flocked to see the old Negro League legend. He finished the regular season with a 6-1 record and 2.48 earned run average, with two shutouts and a save.
The Indians won the American League pennant and beat the Boston Braves in the World Series, where Paige pitched a scoreless two-thirds of an inning.

"Paige seemed to embrace big moments and enjoyed the spotlight," said Raymond Doswell, vice president of curatorial service at the Negro Leagues Baseball Museum in Kansas City, Mo. "He was charismatic and entertaining, confident in his abilities. Confidence made him unafraid of failure."

Despite his grand feats in the Negro Leagues and barnstorming against the best white players, Paige felt pitching in the majors was his real test, "a pressure situation that would give him the chance to ... prove that he was truly one of the best," Norman Macht wrote in "Satchel Paige."
Paige's career spanned five decades. SatchelPaige.com states that some called him the greatest pitcher in Negro Leagues history after such feats as 64 straight scoreless innings and 21 straight wins.

Some of the most accurate records that Tye cites show Paige going 103-61 in the Negro Leagues, 56-7 in the California Winter League, 35-2 in the North Dakota League and 23-11 in the Latin Leagues. In the minor leagues, Paige went 31-22 for the Miami Marlins from 1956 to 1958, when he reached the age of 52. "Age is a case of mind over matter," Paige said. "If you don't mind, it don't matter."
Toward The Hall
In the majors — pitching for the Indians and St. Louis Browns until 1953, then with the Kansas City Athletics in 1965 — he posted a 28-31 record with a solid 3.29 ERA.
In 1971, Paige became the first Negro League pitcher elected to the National Baseball Hall of Fame.
For Paige, pitching was a labor of love: "I ain't ever had a job. I just always played baseball."

Tye said of the traits that made Paige a winner: "Determination was key — the determination ... to get out of his Jim Crow world of the segregated South, and the only way out, he knew, was to prove he could throw a baseball faster and harder than any human being."

Leroy Robert Paige was born in Mobile, Ala., the sixth child of the Paige family. Poverty and segregation made up his life. His nickname Satchel came from working at a depot at age 7. Rather than drag one bag or satchel at a time, he improvised with a pole and rope, which let him tote many.

Two weeks before his 12th birthday in 1918, a resume of fighting, truancy and stealing became the basis for a court order putting him in a black reform school for juveniles. The scared Satchel was ordered to stay until he was 18.
Paige admitted in his 1962 autobiography, "Maybe I'll Pitch Forever," as told to David Lipman, that the reform school prevented him from being a "big bum or crook."
Young Satchel became the leader of the choir and made the drum and bugle corps. He did assigned chores and learned in the classroom.
But it was baseball that became his salvation, courtesy of a coach named Edward Byrd, who taught Satchel fundamentals.
Smart Approach

While the youngster had good size on his way to his adult height of 6 foot 3 inches, Byrd "showed him that physical gifts were not all it took to win," wrote Tye. "Satchel had to outwit his opponent."
Even with his blazing fastball, Paige reflected: "If you can't overpower 'em, outcute 'em."
Paige was also taught how to study a batter to find weaknesses to exploit, and to refine his delivery.

"My coach showed me how to kick up my foot so it looked like I'd blacked out the sky," he wrote. "And he showed me how to swing my arm around so it look like I let go of the ball when my hand was right in the batter's face."

After his reform school release, he returned home, where his mom told him it was time to work and help the family. He ended up making money with the semipro Mobile Tigers, with whom his brother Wilson also pitched.

By the mid-1920s, Paige was pitching for the Chattanooga White Sox of the Negro Southern League. His monthly salary was $250, worth $3,400 today. He'd eventually earn more money than any player, black or white, drawing $30,000 annually — worth $490,000 now — barnstorming in exhibitions.

Paige didn't take his stardom for granted. "I was putting in plenty of hours (of practice) before the other players got up in the mornings and after they went home at nights," he noted. "I'm still trying to rest up from all that practice."
Alex Herman, a former semipro player and owner of the Chattanooga team, mentored Paige.
"Lesson one was location, location, location," Tye wrote. "And the key to great control, Herman reiterated to Paige, was practice."
Paige said his pitching philosophy "is simple: You gotta keep the ball off the fat part of the bat."
So was his strategic approach: "If a man can beat you, walk him."
And his mastery of control: "Just take the ball and throw it where you want to. Throw strikes. Home plate don't move."
Soon before joining the Indians, Paige married for the third time, to Lahoma Brown. The couple had several children, the last one born when Satchel was in his 50s.
Looking Ahead

Paige was 58 when he made that last MLB appearance, with Kansas City, tossing three scoreless innings. Among his rules for staying young was perhaps his most lasting: "Don't look back. Something might be gaining on you."

Paige expanded on what he meant: "When you look back, you know how long you've been going, and that just might stop you from going any farther. And with me, there was an awful lot to look back on. So I didn't. That let me keep on going, and keeping going more than anything else made Ol' Satch the reputation he had. That and a good fastball."At the baseball-ancient age of 42, Satchel Paige achieved his goal of pitching in the majors.It came at a crucial juncture.The Cleveland Indians were in the thick of the 1948 American League pennant race and needed their old rookie to win.When he and those '48 Indians were done, they were champions of the world.Paige (1906-82) was that rare baseball player who, in a sport defined by statistics, transcended them. "And he showed me how to swing my arm around so it look like I let go of the ball when my hand was right in the batter's face."After his reform school release, he returned home, where his mom told him it was time to work and help the family. He ended up making money with the semipro Mobile Tigers, with whom his brother Wilson also pitched.By the mid-1920s, Paige was pitching for the Chattanooga White Sox of the Negro Southern League. His monthly salary was $250, worth $3,400 today. He'd eventually earn more money than any player, black or white, drawing $30,000 annually — worth $490,000 now — barnstorming in exhibitions.Paige didn't take his stardom for granted. "I was putting in plenty of hours (of practice) before the other players got up in the mornings and after they went home at nights," he noted. "I'm still trying to rest up from all that practice."Alex Herman, a former semipro player and owner of the Chattanooga team, mentored Paige."Lesson one was location, location, location," Tye wrote. "And the key to great control, Herman reiterated to Paige, was practice."Paige said his pitching philosophy "is simple: You gotta keep the ball off the fat part of the bat."So was his strategic approach: "If a man can beat you, walk him."And his mastery of control: "Just take the ball and throw it where you want to. Throw strikes. Home plate don't move."Soon before joining the Indians, Paige married for the third time, to Lahoma Brown. The couple had several children, the last one born when Satchel was in his 50s.Looking AheadPaige was 58 when he made that last MLB appearance, with Kansas City, tossing three scoreless innings. Among his rules for staying young was perhaps his most lasting: "Don't look back. Something might be gaining on you."Paige expanded on what he meant: "When you look back, you know how long you've been going, and that just might stop you from going any farther. And with me, there was an awful lot to look back on. So I didn't. That let me keep on going, and keeping going more than anything else made Ol' Satch the reputation he had. That and a good fastball."

At 94, Thurman Miller is one of the last survivors of World War II's Battle of Guadalcanal.
That American triumph in the Pacific in 1943 was a moment that changed the tide of history, like Yorktown and Gettysburg.
Last year, Miller finally wrote about his experience as a member of the 1st Marine Division, nicknamed the Old Breed.

Miller's Company K, 3rd Battalion, 5th Regiment (K/3/5 in Marine jargon) became the most famous riflemen in the war, thanks to Eugene Sledge's account of later campaigns in "With the Old Breed: At Peleliu and Okinawa."

"I had self-published several books starting when I was 80, to share my memories with family and friends," Miller, author of "Earned in Blood: My Journey From Old Breed Marine to the Most Dangerous Job in America," told IBD from his home in the Beckley, W.Va. , area. "They convinced me that this was a story that deserved a bigger audience."
Ahead Of The War

"He was one of the few who joined the Marine Corps pre-Pearl Harbor, and his superiors noted his leadership ability very quickly," Richard Frank, author of "Guadalcanal: The Definitive Account of the Landmark Battle," wrote in the introduction to Miller's book.

Miller was born into a farm family in 1919 in West Virginia's Appalachian coal country. His mother brought eight kids from a prior marriage to join the five from his father's first, and they would have five more who would grow to be adults. They had no electricity, heating or plumbing, but they were happy, he says.
"Living off the land prepared him for the South Pacific better than any urban upbringing would have, and probably saved his life," said his son David, who edited "Earned in Blood."
In early 1940, at age 20, Miller joined the Marines and was assigned to what would soon be named the 1st Marine Division.

He was sent to Cuba to learn jungle fighting and amphibious landings with the new Higgins boat, which could transport a whole platoon. Miller made sergeant before the bombing of Pearl Harbor in December 1941.

In May 1942, the 1st Division was ordered to New Zealand and Fiji to prepare for an amphibious landing that would turn out to be on Guadalcanal, part of the Solomon Islands in the southwestern Pacific.

The successful defense of Midway Island by air and sea forces the next month was the first time the U.S. blunted Japan's rapid expansion through Asia and the Pacific islands. Guadalcanal would test the Allied plan to capture islands and build bases closer to Japan.

The campaign of 1942-43 pitted Marines who had not seen combat against Japanese veterans of ruthless jungle warfare. If the Americans failed to take Guadalcanal, they would have to wait for the European war to wind down to use Russia as a base, strategists said.

On Aug. 7, 1942, a Marine force of 11,000 landed without resistance, catching the Japanese by surprise. But attacks on the U.S. Navy's ships caused them to pull back before many supplies could be delivered. Suddenly the Marines had no protection by aircraft or naval guns, and started running out of food, medicine and ammo.

Japanese artillery bombarded the Marine positions at night. The day brought bombing from planes and shells from ships. Rain was as constant as malaria, dengue fever and dysentery. The Marines were down to one meal of wormy rice a day. But they kept advancing.

"The Japanese fought with an intensity that appeared disproportionate to their likelihood of success to us," wrote Miller. "Fighting to the last man barbarized those who had to kill them, and their atrocities inflamed us in a way that is difficult to understand today."

By October, the Allies had 23,000 troops on Guadalcanal and had a handle on the enemy's human-wave attacks. The Japanese would finally evacuate in February 1943, but most of the fighting was over when the 1st Division left in December 1942 for a break in Australia.

The division received the first of its three Presidential Unit Citations, suffering 650 killed, 1,300 wounded, 31 missing and 8,000 cases of malaria. But it had inflicted almost half of the 31,000 enemy deaths, many of them irreplaceable veterans, pilots and technicians.

A best-selling account by a reporter, Richard Tregaskis, in his book "Guadalcanal Diary," which was made into a movie in 1943. The battles of the 1st Division were portrayed in HBO's "The Pacific," which won a 2010 Emmy for best miniseries.
Tech And Talk

"There were two critical lessons that came out of the experience," said Miller. "One was the importance of improving communications systems because we relied on wires, while the Japanese had handheld radios. The other was the need to train for self-reliance and improvisation, which the 1st Division showed daily, while Japanese soldiers rigidly followed orders and lacked initiative.

"They thought Guadalcanal was an embarrassment and, because of their warrior code of bushido, refused to discuss it. While Americans at home were inspired by the news of battles to make their own sacrifices, the Japanese government's secrecy made it impossible for their people to experience the same type of coming together for the war effort."

After replacing casualties and recuperating, Miller and the 1st Division began retraining in April 1943. At the end of December, they headed for Cape Gloucester on New Britain, the largest island of Papua New Guinea, north of Australia.

The Japanese had used New Britain to launch air and sea attacks on Guadalcanal. The Marines were up against an elite unit of veterans and harsh conditions — with thicker jungle, intense heat, torrential rain, pythons, crocodiles, giant spiders and rats, earthquakes, lightning and the usual diseases.

Progress amounted to gaining 10 feet a day toward the enemy while being bombed. When the Battle of Cape Gloucester began, Miller's company had 242 enlisted men and 10 officers. When the harshest of the fighting subsided 10 days later, the outfit was down to 88 enlisted men and two officers who could fight. Their last engagement was in March 1944, but the Japanese would hold out until the end of the war the next year.
Survival
Three-quarters of the men of K Company at Guadalcanal had been killed, wounded or sent home with malaria. Miller survived.

"The Marine Corps elevated him to the exalted rank of gunnery sergeant, a position occupied only by men deemed to epitomize the highest qualities of field leadership and savvy," wrote Frank. "He was offered the job of top sergeant of K/3/5 if he would go on to what proved to be Peleliu. Thurman turned it down, admitting a powerful sense that his luck (was) running out."
One of the Old Breed at 24, he sailed for America in May 1944 and was given 30 days leave to go home. He married Recie, his girlfriend before the war, and they would have two sons and one daughter.

By the end of 1944, he was at Camp Lejeune, N.C., where he prepared men for combat and rose to chief instructor for new officers. He passed the exam for first sergeant and was about to return to the front line when news came of the Japanese surrender. He was discharged from the Marines in September 1945.

Back in West Virginia, he made his way to Otsego, near Beckley, and dug into coal mining. "There was no place to stand or stretch, doing backbreaking work in a haze of dust and the constant threat of cave-in or explosion," he said. The confinement triggered hallucinations before anyone knew what post-traumatic stress disorder was.
In 1970, after taking courses in electrical machinery, Miller got a job repairing mine locomotives until he retired 10 years later.

"My father really exemplifies the value of hard work, persistence and continuous learning," said David Miller. "He's a tireless reader and began writing notes about his experiences decades ago with no intention of publishing a book, and now he's on Facebook, emails daily and does video editing."

In 1982, Mo Darsey, a K/3/5 member, visited Miller at his new home in Beckley. Miller had avoided contact with his wartime buddies for lack of time and money, and a fear of revisiting the horrors. Now Darsey "made me realize there was a bond that existed between those who had been to hell and back, and I had to renew their acquaintance."

They attended the 1st Division reunion the next year in Milwaukee. Members later visited Camp Lejeune together and, said Miller, "came away feeling that our country was still in good hands."At 94, Thurman Miller is one of the last survivors of World War II's Battle of Guadalcanal.That American triumph in the Pacific in 1943 was a moment that changed the tide of history, like Yorktown and Gettysburg.Last year, Miller finally wrote about his experience as a member of the 1st Marine Division, nicknamed the Old Breed.Miller's Company K, 3rd Battalion, 5th Regiment (K/3/5 in Marine jargon) became the most famous riflemen in the war, thanks to Eugene Sledge's account of later campaigns in "With the Old Breed: At Peleliu and Okinawa.""I had self-published several books starting when I was 80, to share my memories with family and friends," Miller, author of "Earned in Blood: My Journey From Old Breed Marine to the Most Dangerous Job in America," told IBD from his home in the Beckley, W.Va. , area. Treasury 10-year note yields reached the highest in more than three months after data showed durable goods orders rose in November more than forecast, boosting the case for the Federal Reserve to slow bond-buying further.U.S. government securities fell for a second day as new-home sales exceeded estimates. The Federal Open Market Committee said after its Dec. 17-18 policy meeting it will begin reducing $85 billion in asset purchases next month, citing "growing underlying strength" in the economy."Data over the last month have been fairly strong," said Justin Lederer, an interest-rate strategist at Cantor Fitzgerald in New York, one of 21 primary dealers that trade with the central bank. "The Fed will continue to cut, although it's always going to be data-dependent. I wouldn't be surprised to see higher yields. It's pretty important to look at 3 percent."The yield on the benchmark 10-year note climbed five basis points, or 0.05 percentage point, to 2.98% at 2 p.m. ET. It was the highest level since Sept. 6, when the yield touched 3.01%, the most since July 2011. The price of the 2.75% security due in November 2023 dropped 13/32, or $4.06 per $1,000 face amount, to 98-2/32.Five-year note yields reached 1.74%, the highest since Sept. 13. Thirty-year bond yields advanced four basis points to 3.89%.The Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association recommended a close at 2 p.m. ET for Treasuries, and that trading stay shut Wednesday for the Christmas holiday, according to the group's website.Treasury trading volume at ICAP, the largest inter-dealer broker of U.S. government debt, tumbled 51% Monday to $155.9 billion, the lowest level since Nov. 29, and totaled $85.5 billion at Tuesday's early closing. The daily average this year is $310.6 billion.Yields on Treasuries due in seven years and less may be poised to reverse increases, a technical indicator signaled. The 14-day relative-strength index readings for seven-, five-, three- and two-year notes were all above the 70 level that signals the yields may have jumped too much, too fast, and be about to change direction.The readings were 73.5 for seven-year yields, 76.3 for five-year yields, 77.1 for three-year yields and 77.7 for yields on two-year securities.Treasuries lost 3% this year through Dec. 23, according to the Bloomberg World Bond Indexes, while the Standard & Poor's 500 Index of U.S. equities returned 31 percent including reinvested dividends. The S&P; 500 closed at an all-time high Tuesday for a third straight day.

Treasury 10-year yields rose to the highest level in two months as Federal Reserve officials said they might reduce $85 billion in monthly bond purchases "in coming months" as the economy improves, minutes of their last meeting show.

The difference between the yields on three-year notes and the 30-year bond widened to the most in more than two years as the policy makers expect "ongoing improvement in labor market conditions." Fed Bank of St. Louis President James Bullard said earlier a cutback in the central bank's purchase program is "on the table" for the December meeting, while 5 percent of investors surveyed are looking next month for a Fed decision to taper, according to the latest Bloomberg Global Poll.

"Their outlook is more robust than the general market's," said William Larkin, a fixed-income portfolio manager who helps oversee $500 million at Cabot Money Management Inc., in a telephone interview from Salem, Massachusetts. "It's going to cause the expectation that tapering may come sooner than later."

The benchmark 10-year yield gained nine basis points, or 0.09 percentage point, to 2.80 percent at 3:31 a.m. New York time, according to Bloomberg Bond Trader prices. The 2.75 percent note due in November 2023 dropped 25/32, or $7.81 per $1,000 face amount, to 99 19/32. The yield reached the highest level since Sept. 18.

The extra yield on 30-year bonds compared with three-year notes, known as the yield curve, expanded to 3.34 percentage points, the widest since August 2011. The difference has averaged 2.83 percentage points in the past 12 months. The steeper curve suggests investors are demanding a higher premium to hold longer maturities amid signs growth will pick up and spur inflation.

"The fact that they didn't overtly lower the unemployment threshold" helped to steepen the yield curve, said David Ader, U.S. government bond-strategy head at CRT Capital Group LLC in Stamford, Connecticut.
The minutes show "a couple supported reducing the 6.5 percent unemployment rate threshold, while others said that change may cause concern about how committed the Fed is to the thresholds."

Four of five investors expect the Fed to delay a decision to begin reducing its bond buying until March 2014 or later, with just 5 percent looking for a move next month, according to the latest Bloomberg Global Poll.

Those forecasting a cutback in March or later in the poll are split evenly between those who expect a move that month and those who see it afterward.Treasury 10-year yields rose to the highest level in two months as Federal Reserve officials said they might reduce $85 billion in monthly bond purchases "in coming months" as the economy improves, minutes of their last meeting show.The difference between the yields on three-year notes and the 30-year bond widened to the most in more than two years as the policy makers expect "ongoing improvement in labor market conditions." Driven to help solve their clients' problems, advisors tend to derive great satisfaction from their work. But sometimes, mundane aspects of the job get in the way.Dealing with administrative hassles, compliance issues, and squabbles among staffers can lead to burnout. Conducting daily client reviews can turn what was once a stimulating experience into boring, repetitive drudgery.Ensnared in a workaday routine, advisors may not notice their eroding enthusiasm until it's too late. As their listlessness deepens into a more serious funk, they can lose their spark and might dread coming into the office.The most attentive advisors ward off burnout before it intensifies. They take proactive steps — such as taking time off or at least not overloading their schedule — so that they stay fresh and committed to providing excellent service."Years of ups and downs in the market can wear on you," said Tony Perrone, an advisor in Orlando, Fla. "And then there's what I call 'compliance burnout' with all the changes in compliance that can seem overwhelming."For Perrone, 47, the solution is adopting a four-day workweek as much as possible. For the last four years, he has taken off most Fridays."It's a good remedy that lets the staff catch up with you not there," he said. "You give them that time to breathe, and that makes them happier. When they're in a better mood, I'm in a better mood the other four days."Perrone acknowledges that he has the option to take one day off a week because he's paid his dues. He launched his career 24 years ago, and he says that for the first 20 years "you've got to run full speed."He cites two side benefits from skipping most Fridays. For starters, Perrone feels less compelled to take extended vacations. He says that the longest he's been away from the office is five business days."And I probably took 10 client calls that week," he added.Second, his three employees enjoy operating autonomously when he's not around. His absence gives them a chance to take more responsibility and build stronger relationships with clients.Other advisors view sabbaticals as a welcome option to combat a midcareer lull. Taking a month or more to step away from the business can reignite an advisor's passion.A handful of larger firms offer sabbaticals, and some implement programs to encourage advisors to recharge periodically. A few firms go further, requiring advisors to take extended leave.At BKD Wealth Advisors, every advisor takes a one-month paid sabbatical every five years. It's a non-negotiable condition of employment."The firm asks a lot from you for the other four years and 11 months," said Jack Thurman, managing partner at the Springfield, Mo.-based company. "Everyone loves the sabbatical."Over the 17 years that BKD's program has been in place, Thurman has qualified for three sabbaticals. He's enjoyed leisure travel, including fly fishing, and spent the last week at home to smooth the transition back to the office.Part of the rationale for mandatory sabbaticals is that it forces advisors to provide extensive professional development to employees. They must train their team to handle myriad tasks while they're away for a month."We believe that you have to be replaceable and set up duplicative processes," Thurman said. "You have to teach people to be better than you. A sabbatical won't be successful for those who don't like to delegate."To minimize disruption, BKD advisors commit to their month off a year in advance. This enables colleagues to plan for their absence.During their month away, they cannot access their work email or voice mail. Co-workers provide client service and manage other duties so that the advisor can relax without worrying about paperwork piling up."You turn it off for one full month and you turn it off hard," Thurman said. "When you get back, you should have no email, so there's no need to play catch-up."The forced vacation allows some midcareer advisors to reassess their careers. Thurman says that while some partners in their 50s return with renewed verve, others decide to take early retirement. The sabbatical thus affords them a chance to reflect on their personal and professional priorities.Thurman, 55, returned from his last sabbatical two years ago with a clearer picture of how he intends to harness his energy. To pave the way for his retirement, he seeks to create a lasting system of excellence."I want to leave a legacy at this firm," he said. "I'm focusing on a good risk structure and building operational efficiencies so that when I leave, I've laid the groundwork for a successful transition."RELATED:Top Advisors Discuss Their Most Valuable LessonsStarting Over: Setbacks Vanquished And Lessons Learned

Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) is telling advertisers it's stepping up spending on YouTube's original content, but Google's programming slate will still look much different from that of big-budget producers Netflix (NFLX) or Amazon.com (AMZN).At an annual advertising event Thursday night, Google hinted at spending hundreds of millions of dollars for new, professionally produced original content, as opposed to its regular fare of uploaded video. But its spending will still pale in comparison to that of Amazon and Netflix — both of which have scored awards for TV shows and movies.Amazon is set to spend some $4.5 billion on video in 2017, JPMorgan estimated in April, while Netflix's tab could top $6.5 billion.Google told advertisers it will team with celebrities Kevin Hart, Katy Perry and Ellen DeGeneres to create shows as well as YouTube's own stars, Rhett & Link and The Slow Mo Guys. Singer Demi Lovato is also expected to produce a TV show.Google also spends on content for YouTube Red, a $10 monthly subscription service without advertising. Google launched YouTube Red in late 2015, but hasn't disclosed subscriber totals.YouTube Red's originals have been mostly spun off from a roster of young stars who developed large audiences with their ad-supported videos. Google, at the advertising event, reportedly told agencies that it's increasing spending on high-quality programming.IBD'S TAKE: Alphabet stock has climbed 20% in 2017, with much of that gain coming in low volume since it reported Q1 earnings. Alphabet stock is extended from an 874.52 technical buy point but has underperformed its FANG (Facebook, Amazon.com, Netflix) peers. Learn more about Alphabet's chart pattern at IBD Stock Checkup.  Unlike Netflix and Amazon, Google has not been buying up rights to independently produced films or big-budget TV shows.Google has been spreading its bets in video streaming. In April it launched a $35 monthly service with live-TV broadcast content in five cities, including New York, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Chicago and Philadelphia.Google has worked to provide advertisers with improved audience-measurement tools.Alphabet shares fell 0.5% to 950.28 on the stock market today. Amazon and Netflix dipped 0.4%. All are close to record highs, with Netflix reversing from an all-time best intraday.RELATED:Media Giants Dive On Ad Woes; Hulu Debuts Live-TV ServiceThis Is What Google Won't Tell You About YouTube's FinancialsGoogle Traffic-Cost Worries Fade Away As Long As Earnings BeatGoogle Working To End Ad Flap That Derailed Stock Rally

The Obama administration claimed that it negotiated with Syria and Russia to eliminate "100%" of Syria's chemical weapons. After President Barack Obama's 2012 "red line" warning to Syria about using chemical weapons, Syria launched a chemical attack in August 2013. But U.S. military action was avoided by the alleged Russian/American/Syrian diplomatic accomplishment, achieved without "firing a shot." Here's what we were told:President Obama, on April 28, 2014: "We're getting chemical weapons out of Syria without having initiated a strike."Sen. Claire McCaskill, D-Mo., crowed on June 1, 2014: "We're getting the chemical weapons out of Syria." And Sen. Bob Casey, D-Pa., chimed in July 6: "We should commend the administration for the result that they got."Then-Secretary of State John Kerry, on July 20, 2014: "We got 100% of the chemical weapons out (of Syria)."President Obama, on Aug. 18, 2014: "Today we mark an important achievement in our ongoing effort to counter the spread of weapons of mass destruction by eliminating Syria's declared chemical weapons stockpile."Kerry on Oct. 31, 2014: "We ... cut the deal that got 100% of the declared chemical weapons out of Syria, and people nevertheless have been critical — of one day of bombing versus the virtue of getting 100% of the chemical weapons out of Syria."Kerry reiterated the accomplishment on Feb. 24, 2015, telling the Senate Foreign Relations Committee: "We got, as you know, last year, all the chemical weapons out of Syria."True, Bloomberg reported on May 13, 2015: "The U.S. government was informed months ago that an international monitoring body found traces of chemical weapons that President Bashar al-Assad had promised to turn over, including sarin gas — a clear violation of the deal he struck with President Obama after crossing the administration's 'red line' two years ago."Officials from the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons told the Obama administration early this year that its inspectors had found traces of two banned chemical weapons during an inspection of the Syrian government's Scientific Studies and Research Center in the district of Barzeh near Damascus, two administration officials told us. A report by Reuters May 8 said that OPCW inspectors had found traces of sarin and VX nerve agent at the site in separate inspections in December and January."After the Bloomberg story, then-White House press secretary John Earnest initially admitted: "We're aware that the OPCW continues to receive credible allegations that the use of chemical weapons in Syria is still taking place." But a month later, on June 17, 2015, Earnest responded: "(Syria's) declared chemical weapons stockpile that Assad previously denied existed has now been acknowledged, rounded up, removed from the country and destroyed precisely because of the work of this administration and our successful efforts to work with the Russians to accomplish that goal."But Susan Rice, then Obama's national security adviser, on Jan. 16, 2017, said, "We were able to find a solution that didn't necessitate the use of force that actually removed the chemical weapons that were known from Syria, in a way that the use of force would never have accomplished. ... We were able to get the Syrian government to voluntarily and verifiably give up its chemical weapons stockpile."After last week's chemical weapons attack that left nearly 100 Syrians dead, former Obama advisers now say they always knew that not all of chemical weapons were eliminated — and that turning over all their weapons is not exactly what tyrants tend to do.Antony J. Blinken, a former deputy secretary of state, recently said, "We always knew we had not gotten everything, that the Syrians had not been fully forthcoming in their declaration."Michael McFaul, Obama's former ambassador to Russia, said, "For me, this tragedy underscores the dangers of trying to do deals with dictators without a comprehensive, invasive and permanent inspection regime."Tom Malinowski, an assistant secretary of state for human rights under Obama, laments: "The difficult and debatable choice the Obama administration ... made not to use military force when Assad last used nerve gas against his people (in 2013) will shape our thinking about this and similar crises for a long time to come. The lesson I would draw from that experience is that when dealing with mass killing by unconventional or conventional means, deterrence is more effective than disarmament."This brings us the Obama's Iran deal that allegedly prevents Iran from acquiring a nuclear weapon. Why should we believe that Obama was any less duped here than when he claimed the elimination of "all" of Syria's chemical weapons?We shouldn't.

In October 1945, as he prepared to announce the signing of Jackie Robinson to break the color barrier in Major League Baseball, Branch Rickey visited his friend, the well-known broadcaster Lowell Thomas."Branch, all hell will break loose!" Thomas told Rickey, as recounted by Lee Lowenfish in "Branch Rickey: Baseball's Ferocious Gentleman." "No, Lowell," Rickey replied. "All heaven will rejoice."Rickey, then the Brooklyn Dodgers' president and general manager, is remembered for his courage and foresight in breaking baseball's color line, the unofficial racial barrier which had stood firmly since the late 1800s. Robinson played his first game as a major leaguer 70 years ago this week.Rickey often said that he was drawn to the cause of racial equality when, in 1903, he observed Charles Thomas, the only black member of the Ohio Wesleyan University baseball team, being denied a hotel room in South Bend, Ind. "I never felt so helpless in my life," said Rickey.A 1949 Newsweek profile noted that Rickey spent "two intensely secretive years" considering the implications of breaking baseball's color barrier, not even informing the Dodgers' scouting department of his potential move."When Robinson was signed, it effectively opened up the biggest pool of talent in history," said Daniel R. Levitt, co-author with Mark L. Armour of "In Pursuit of Pennants: Baseball Operations from Deadball to Moneyball."Rickey's innovations are seen throughout baseball today. He established the first "farm system" for developing major league talent and encouraged the use of statistical analysis in evaluating players. He promoted modern training methods and equipment.More broadly, Rickey elevated and exemplified the baseball general manager position, a role that most often had been taken on by an owner or team president. Under Rickey, it would include everything from player development to scouting.Rickey left an "unmatched resume in the game," wrote Armour.  "As a general manager he dramatically changed how teams find and develop players, and what players are allowed to play the game. His place as the greatest GM in baseball history is secure."Wesley Branch Rickey (1881-1965) was born in Stockdale, Ohio, to Frank and Emily Rickey. Lowenfish writes that the family had a "hardscrabble existence," trying to subsist on a vegetable farm.Born into a pious family, Rickey's name derived from John Wesley, a founder of Methodism. The name "Branch" came from scripture, possibly from a passage in the Old Testament.Rickey studied at Ohio Wesleyan, arriving on campus as "the picture of the hayseed," according to Lowenfish, and experienced a difficult transition. He made his mark on both the football and baseball fields, showing "plenty of pep and ginger" as a catcher.In 1903, Rickey witnessed the stellar performance of Charles Follis, who is believed to have been the first black professional football player. Follis' on-field achievements, combined with his poise in the face of racial pressures, impressed Rickey, planting a seed for his determination years later to integrate baseball.After signing a minor league baseball contract in 1903, Rickey debuted in the majors with the St. Louis Browns in 1905. His playing career over four seasons was pedestrian. While catching, he allowed a stunning 13 stolen bases in a single game, setting a dubious record. Following an arm injury and a bout of tuberculosis, Rickey enrolled at the University of Michigan Law School. He also became the baseball coach at Michigan.In 1913, Rickey became an executive for the Browns, signing future Hall of Famer George Sisler and later managing the team for more than two seasons. In 1919, Rickey joined the St. Louis Cardinals as team manager and president. In 1925, he was fired as manager by owner Sam Breadon, a serendipitous move which allowed Rickey to focus exclusively on being an executive.Rickey revamped the Cardinals' roster, laying the groundwork for six pennants and four World Series during his 24 seasons there. He quickly released players who did not meet his standards, turning around a previously mediocre franchise. Rickey acquired eventual stars Joe Medwick and brothers Dizzy and Daffy Dean, who shaped the Cardinals' "Gashouse Gang" in the 1930s.Though Commissioner Kenesaw Mountain Landis was dismissive of Rickey's farm system, fearing it would destroy the existing structure, Rickey used it to great success.  The World Series-winning 1942 Cardinals were built with players Rickey's system developed, including Stan Musial, the best player in franchise history.Rickey reshaped the entire organization:"The farm system allowed Rickey to institute the 'Cardinal Way,' " said Levitt.  "It was an organizational philosophy extending from the lowest farmhands to the Major League team. It instituted organizationwide training techniques and defined what sort of players the team's scouts would seek.  There became a pride in being a Cardinal. Rickey was the first baseball executive to develop this kind of organizational framework."Rickey joined the Dodgers before the 1943 season. The core players of Brooklyn's six World Series teams between 1947 and 1956 were acquired and developed under Rickey. With Brooklyn, Rickey hired the first team statistician, opened a team spring training facility in Vero Beach, Fla., and implemented new training techniques, including the use of pitching machines.Rickey was acutely aware that he needed to sign the right player to break baseball's color barrier."Mr. Rickey knew he needed a superb player or the man wouldn't stand a chance," said Carl Erskine, a member of the Dodgers from 1948 through 1959 and a teammate of Jackie Robinson for nine seasons. "Robinson was a four-letter man at UCLA. His best sport may have been football, not baseball.  And he had to be intelligent.  Jackie certainly was."Mr. Rickey said to Jackie: 'If a fight starts on the field, I'm picking you. You're quicker, you're faster, and you're stronger. You're going to win the fight. But are you strong enough not to fight? You must tell me that you're willing to commit yourself not to fight.' When Jackie said, 'I think I can do it,' Mr. Rickey read to him a paraphrased version of 'Turn the Other Cheek,' a verse in the Bible, about having the courage to resist."Rickey, according to Erskine, stressed the Christian faith of both of their mothers in making his plea and offer to Robinson. "That was a critical moment, often unmentioned in history, when Jackie made the commitment."Robinson, who debuted 70 years ago this week, was National League Rookie of the Year in 1947 and led Brooklyn to the World Series. Robinson's struggles and triumphs are an integral part of American history, and his importance to baseball and its growth is immense.Rickey encouraged Cleveland to sign Larry Doby, the first African-American to play in the American League, because he did not want to "corner the market on black players," wrote Lowenfish."Mr. Rickey unselfishly gave up a Hall of Famer for the American League to be integrated," said Erskine. "That was selfless and is too often forgotten."The African-American players whom Rickey signed, including Don Newcombe and Roy Campanella, were central to Brooklyn's success throughout the 1950s. After losing a power struggle, Rickey left the Dodgers for the Pittsburgh Pirates in 1950. While the team struggled during his time as general manager, Rickey acquired many of the top players on Pittsburgh's 1960 World Series-winning team, including Roberto Clemente."There was no one quite as good at seeing greatness in raw talent," Lowenfish told IBD. "In evaluating players and hiring quality scouts, nobody quite matches Rickey."But, while his farm system allowed him to acquire players cheaply, "he was hated because he made the money and the players didn't," said Lowenfish. Erskine said that Rickey was often referred to as El Cheapo, connoting a reputation for miserliness which Rickey had difficulty shaking, even though he sometimes spent profusely on players.Some suggested that Rickey's decision to sign Robinson also had underlying financial motivations.  Others criticized Rickey for never coming to the ballpark on Sundays, as he honored the Sabbath to pay homage to his mother.Erskine said that Rickey tested players, trying to learn how they processed information."He helped many players excel, through his patience and his unique methods. In spring training, he used to talk to players as they worked out. He wanted to see if you had aptitude."He had a $5 bill which he'd lay on home plate. He'd say: 'Son, I want you to throw the ball with your hand backwards to the plate. If you can hit that $5, you can have it.' He often gave us little tests which helped him make judgments about players. He wanted to know if you could learn unconventionally."On Dec. 9, 1965, Rickey died at age 83 of heart failure in Columbia, Mo. Nearly a month earlier, he had collapsed while giving a speech during his induction to the Missouri Sports Hall of Fame and never regained consciousness. He was survived by his wife, Jane, and five daughters."Mr. Rickey was a human dynamo," said Erskine. "He truly kept going until he stopped."Rickey's most prominent contribution will always be signing Robinson to break baseball's color barrier:"To me, Rickey and Robinson were the right combination," said Lowenfish. "The years when they were together were vital to the country. Rickey was the indispensable man in that move. He also deserves credit for two other revolutions: the farm system and trying to establish the Continental League, a rival league which didn't succeed but which certainly prompted expansion."What he was able to achieve was remarkable. Given his humble beginnings and extraordinary achievements, Rickey really was the Horatio Alger story writ large."Innovative baseball executive who helped break baseball's color barrier by signing Jackie Robinson.Overcame: Widespread resistance to baseball's integration and to many of his innovations.Lesson: Importance of thinking strategically and maintaining focus on long-term goals regardless of opposition."Ethnic prejudice has no place in sports, and baseball must recognize that truth if it is to maintain stature as a national game."MORE ABOUT LEADERS:Roy Campanella Was A BattlerEwing Kauffman Applied His Winning Formula To Sales, Education, BaseballVin Scully Prepared To Become Baseball's Master Storyteller
